description: I love this hidden gem. It's cash only and inside this dim bar it takes you back to gastropubs like in Europe.
author: Miguel E.

description:
A decent neighborhood dive with a fairly large beer selection. Most of the brews are default, recognizable names like PBR, Stella, and Anchor Steam, but there are also a few gems like the Russian River Pliny the Elder DIPA and the New Holland Dragon's Milk stout. 

Service is perfunctory, although to their credit they were able to handle large crowds when I stopped by. The venue is a bit narrow but is also more elongated than you might think; the front portion feels like a man cave from the '50s or '60s while a rear portion has lots of games (all paid) and feels a bit like a hunters' lodge. Overall, an OK go-to if you live in the area.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The Page is an average neighborhood corner bar that's not the best bar ever but not the worst. They're a cash-only joint that has no cocktail menu, a pool and foosball table, and some classy furniture. My wife and I were killing some time here waiting to eat omokase at Ijji located on the same block. We shot pool with some nice hipster-type people and enjoyed some Lone Star Texas beer ($4.50). I'd probably only visit this bar again if I was in the area for something random or if I knew someone who lived by it.

Pool table costs $1.50 a game--SF prices!
author: Marlon T.

description:
Great neighborhood bar with awesome selection of beer - and new (at least to me) a handly little printed menu of beers with ABV, IBU, description and cost which is handy to make the right choices.

Slightly Jekyll and Hyde-esque in terms of atmosphere. In the late afternoon/early evening it's a chill, dog friendly locals bar (with a great happy hour as well) that's a relaxing place to hang out for a couple of drinks.

After 8pm, dogs aren't allowed (fair enough - the rules are very clear) and it gets much busier and louder with a younger crowd there to party and play pool.

I'm more a fan of the chilled afternoon side of this equation but either way it's a great spot to grab a few interesting beers without the attitude you sometimes get at Toronado...
author: Diarmuid R.

description: Favorite bar! Cash only but beers and other drinks are cheap. Come for happy hour where drafts are $1 off. Cool atmosphere with fun people. It's not super loud so you can easily carry on conversation.
author: Alexandra L.

description: Love this place. Perfect neighborhood bar. Great beers on tap, plus a good bottle selection too. If you're looking for a great, non-pompous Friday night this is the place to go'
author: Eugene B.

description:
Randy is the worst bartender ever!!
Super attentive, super inattentive
Super nice! Super not nice




If it wasn't for the lighting I'd never come back!
author: Emmy M.

description: Awesome low-key bar with inexpensive drinks (cash only, though). It can get pretty packed, so be on the lookout for seats or arrive early. I'm a fan and will definitely be back.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Came into The Page on Easter--it was pretty packed for a Sunday and a rainy one at that, but it was fine. This Bar is pretty neat, great location on Divis and they have a small lower level with a foosball table, some sort of arcade game (competitive variety game? I think there's pacman on it) and a pool table. We stopped by to play a couple rounds of pool after Easter Lunch. The pool table is expensive! $1.50 to play a game (most places I know are $1 or free) but they do have two of them, one on the upper level and one on the lower one which is cool.

It's a pretty chill/small bar with fairly reasonable drinks during HH. Your standard chill place to grab a drink and play a round with some friends. There was only one bartender who seemed a bit swamped and one of our friends would grab a round for people and collect cups (she didn't even work there! but she'd go back and forth with 10 cups and bring back a round) but they were super short staffed and things were piling up everywhere.

Pretty chill divey place. Can't stay too long, those pool games will add up!
author: Nerissa C.

description:
Woman with the black and white long sleeve that read "I like long walks to the bar" charged me $14 for two vodka sodas while the woman at the front bar with brown hair charged my homie $10 for two vodka sodas.


I don't like being mis-charged. C'mon Page! 
GET YOUR SHIT TOGETHER.
author: Laurie M.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon with my girlfriend, lady bartender was not friendly in the least. Not only was she very hostile with me I heard her bad mouthing customers and scoffing audibly about a group who left her a "bad" tip. 

Giving this place two stars because the drinks were good and the location is cool however the bartender didn't make us feel like staying long. Would not come here again...bad vibes
author: Dylan H.

description:
Nothing is more satisfying than landing at the airport and still having the energy to go out. I kept insisting that I would be too tired, but my friend was going to The Page and wanted me to join him. It had been awhile since hanging out on Divisadero, so I went and was glad that I did!

The Page is your typical dive bar, complete with dim lighting and pool tables. It's much bigger (deeper) than I thought. I grabbed a beer at the bar and proceeded to watch my friend and his friends play pool. I'll have to fit in a game myself next time. We eventually migrated to the lower level (more lighting there) and hung out some more. Chill place to hang out. Nothing special. Feels like a cozy place that's easy to become a regular at.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Decent house bourbon, mellow ambience, and a helpful bartender. Came during happy hour and it didn't break the bank. Going to come again.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
Slummy, divey bar around Haight. I'm not usually a fan of dive bars, but I liked that they had pool tables and a foosball table (they cost money though!). If you're looking for a quieter spot to hang out with friends where you can actually hold and hear a conversation without yelling, it's worth checking out. 

Cash only! They also have an ATM in the very back in case you don't have any on you.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Discovered The Page a couple years ago, while visiting another business across the street. Quickly became a fan of the vibe and music, which tends to sprinkle some 80's alternative in the mix.
The staff is really nice too ;)
author: LL O.

description: I came in after a long game of ultimate frisbee and Randy the bartender told me that since I wasn't playing a real sport, he wouldn't serve me a Tecate.
author: Anna S.

description:
Layla Makes the best cocktails in the city. Her favorite is named the French 75. You guys should check it out.

Her smile entices one to return for many of their wonderful cocktails; moreover, her customer service and attention to detail is sublime. I'd happily suggest tasting her mixes.
author: Cullen D.

description: I've never really enjoyed The Page, which always seems grimy and crowded, but not in a fun way. I'm sure I'd feel differently if it were my neighborhood bar, but it's not. However, I do like the beer selection and once I find a corner to squirrel myself away in, it's certainly all right.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Pros
- Good happy hour spot 
- Good selection of beers
- Great bartenders
- There are a few pool tables

Cons 
- Can get really crowded on weekend nights
author: Dipesh G.

description: The place reminds me of a whacky uncle's "man cave", and that's just fine with me. I'll come here to play some locals in pool in the back. The staff is kind though are a bit short with you if it's busy. I don't blame them. Overall, a good place to wind down after a long week.
author: Joe D.

description:
Great dive bar in the Haight area of San Francisco. I headed there with my wife and some buddies on Saturday of the Halloween weekend, it was jumping. 

Staff were very friendly and quick to get us all served despite the crowd.  Music was great, PBR was cheap - all I could ask for! 

Next time I'm back in San Fran I'll def pop in for a wee beer again.  See you on the next page :)
author: Stuart B.

description:
This is my neighborhood bar - dive-y, reasonably priced, and stumbling distance to my place.  Overall, the patrons are a casual, chill crowd and the bartenders are efficient, friendly, and pour a good drink.  It's gotten more hipster-y in the last several years, but remains a neighbor watering hole more than many other places.

The women's restroom is small and stuffy, but definitely not the most disgusting dive bar restroom I've seen.  Rumor has it that the men's may be less acceptable, but I can't say with certainty.

The interior reminds me of a Midwestern basement from the 1970s, complete w ugly, dirty carpet (that likely smells, but I am never going to smell the carpet at The Page!) and taxidermy decor.  And, like many of those basements that I can recall from my youth, the decor hasn't changed since it was first installed...and I think that's a good thing and part of the "charm" of The Page :)

There's a pool table, a foosball table and a juke box.  All three tend to seemingly always be occupied.

Minus one star for being cash only.  Though I admit, it probably helps make service really quick at the bar.
author: Sara E.

description: This is a great little place to go have drinks with friends. In addition to the bar, there is also some seating away that is a bit more quite. Overall, great place. Good beer selection. I recommend giving it a try.
author: Anthony H.

description:
I didn't even know that Yelp had a "pool halls" category, but The Page does indeed have two pool tables, plus foosball in the back! Not really my thing, but it's fun for hanging out with groups of friends. The ambience is a little on the divey side, closer to a neighborhood bar than somewhere you dress up and go out to on a Friday night. It was crowded even on a Thursday night at 8pm, but the vibe was pretty chill. The floorplan is long and rectangular though, so the back can get a little warm and stuffy.

No special cocktail menu, but they do have a full bar, decent beer selection, and cheap wine by the glass. CASH ONLY!! I did not know that when I was there; luckily, I happened to have some cash on me.
author: Tiffany P.

description: I went here for some drinks with friends one night and I really liked it. Seems to be a popular spot for mid to late 20 year olds. There's a pool table in the back but it had a long line so if you're set on playing pool I would suggest getting there early or maybe just going somewhere with more tables. The place is pretty casual but not dive-y since it's decorated in an interesting way. I think the back room is meant to look like a library. I would come back.
author: Mimi H.

description: Awful guy at front of entrance. When a customer goes into the establishment you don't grab him by the arm. My buddy goes in and doesn't get grabbed by the arm. Me being a martial artist you don't grab me by the arm number one im a paying customer. Then when I inform him you shouldn't be doing that because people don't like that he says your out then proceeds to flick me off. This gentleman as some might call him probably not needs to be fired/ reprimanded.
author: Nic C.

description:
Just moved into the neighborhood and have quickly settled on The Page as my regular haunt. This place has a great atmosphere and reasonable drink prices. Whiskey neat ran $6, which is a little better than the going rate in SF, near as I can tell. 

Pretty dive-y. It's deceptively large inside -- the place stretches out pretty far into the back. A shoe-in for my favorite bar on this stretch of Divis.  

I haven't touched the jukebox, but it's one of those new-fangled video screen deals that probably has basically every song on it. Please don't put on "I Don't Want To Miss A Thing" 10 times in a row. (Please put on "I Don't Want To Miss A Thing" 10 times in a row.")
author: Jim M.

description: I like the divy bar - lounge atmosphere The Page provides, as well as the good selection of beers. It would be nice if music was played throughout, however, without customers having to go to the Jukebox and paying out of pocket.
author: Leonora H.

description:
A quintessential neighborhood bar, The Page's long labyrinth-like layout might intimidate non-regulars at first, but the decent selections of beer on tap more than make up for it.   

It's a dark and narrow bar that can be packed with regulars who come for booze, music, video games, foosball, and pool. It can smell a little musty too and finding the restroom requires some climbing up and down but when you factor how much they squeeze into the space, it's pretty impressive. And then there's like 20 beers on tap where none of them are crappy. Nice range of microbrews to local faves served to you by pretty friendly bartenders. 

I'm not a neighborhood regular but The Page is a nice option to grab a quick pint around Lower Haight. Note that they're cash only though.
author: Jon L.

description:
Great feel to this place
Divert classic bar
Great service
Pool table , foosball table
Able to have a conversation 
2 tvs with  sports
author: Jones T.

description:
Yeah, not my kind of place. It's dark and divey, which I get it, is part of the charm for some. But I really wasn't feeling the crowd. A few of the women there seemed very... I don't know... entitled isn't quite the word, but they were definitely hogging the bar and the bartenders' attention and as a dude trying to get a drink, they sort of made it clear that their needs superseded my own, and were rather rude about it. 

The bartender wasn't personable, and it took me forever to get her attention, and then there was absolutely nothing special about my cocktail.

Wouldn't go back. The place annoyed me.
author: Sean B.

description: DJ Dave loves this dive bar and is upset by the recent closure of so many cousins around the city. It's a great pick-up bar so be sure to bring your wingman. If you do go solo, hang by the pool table, join a game, and you'll start meeting folks left and right. Beer is fairly priced, the juke box is well stocked and there are plenty of chances to get lucky, but your odds do diminish the closer it gets to 2:00am when the vampires and gremlins emerge eager to steel your catch. Act quick.
author: Brian J.

description: I visited this place for the first time tonight, for a work happy hour.  Although it might not have been the idea place for a work get together (the seating wasn't ideal for a large group) it was still a great place to get a few drinks.  Anywhere with a good happy hour and a place to read free New Yorker magazines is great in my book.  Also FYI: it's cash only.
author: Grace P.

description:
This bar is just my speed.

Awesome nautical art that feels like it used to live in a hotel. 

Vinyl short backed bar stools.

Crowds of friends.

A pool table. 

Thumbs up all around.

A decent selection of beers on tap is complimented by a solid selection of spirits.

I didn't have any mixed drinks, but I was quite pleased with the beer, which was cold, the company which was warm, and the ambiance which was that perfect mixture of divey unpretentiousness  mixed with an obvious amount of giving a shit. 

I look forward to visiting this bar again.
author: Kipper S.

description: Nice little spot to go for a drink and play some pool. Although the cost per pool game was a little higher than what I'm used to. Note: cash only!
author: Annie G.

description: We came here on a Monday afternoon at 5pm. Our experience has been great: the interior is dimly lit and awesomely decorated, the bartender is super friendly and awesome, the jazz music that they play is so good and relaxing. Overall, a great atmosphere for anyone who just wants to grab a beer and chill. They also have free wifi!
author: Catherine T.

description:
Cool bar, small, close to my place, thats a plus I guess...

Since I need to write more but I have no more to say Here is a random paragraph from a book.

"Helicopter money is a reference to an idea made popular by the American economist Milton Friedman in 1969"
author: Nekario V.

description: Hi Ho silver. Great bar. Young crowd. They are nice. Lots if games in the way back.  Good variety of drinks.  Bar tenders are cool  nice girls. They look like they know what they're doing.  I like the margaritas.  They are served in a funny cactus cup
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I have nothing but love for this neighborhood dive bar.

The Page makes me feel like I've been transported to the 70's because the inside is very Harold and Maude. Everything is red and soft.

Patrons and staff are quality, dive-loving folk. Drinks are stiff. There's a couple different pool tables. This is a good spot to just grab a drink with a handful of people.

Also don't be an ass - bring cash, they're cash-only.

^Personally, I'm that asshole. I don't bring cash and then my friend has to buy me drinks. Maybe they won't catch on...
author: K M.

description:
Nice bar that I've been several times.  It's chill, can't say anything bad nor anything special.  Workers are friendly.

-Small little fooseball table thats generally open
-2 pool tables (one wasn't used last time for some reason)
author: Samuel Y.

description:
Dark and a little divey, with a lot of fun beers. Check the selections on the chalk boards above the bar, but be sure to ask if you're looking for something specific - they might have it or something like it on a super secret tap or in the bottle. The bartender was able to recommend us a really, really good sour that wasn't on the menu.

Minus half a star for being cash only, minus a full star for the ATM being broken.
author: Rachel M.

description: Dark and Divey... The way a bar should be.  This is my little sis's Go To bar so she brought me in on my visit.  They have a juke box, two pool tables, and a fooze ball table.  The drinks were stiff, the service was good, and we had a great time.
author: Bryanna P.

description: If I could give it 0 stars I would. Bartender was absolutely horrible. Ordered a vodka soda and couldn't taste any vodka. My party ordered 3 and didn't drink more than a sip each. The bartender said she "didn't mind" and made no attempt to accommodate paying customers. TERRIBLE SERVICE!!!! DO NOT GO!!!!
author: Resham R.

description:
Women who say they become invisible when the reached middle age weren't kidding.

I want to the Page tonight for a drink. Simple enough. I stood in line behind a few people waiting to order. When I got to the front, I waited for the male bartender (Randy?)to help me. 

He turned around-and asked the girl behind me what she wanted. She told him (a can beer) and he then reached over my shoulder to take her money.

To clarify: I'm standing right in front of him, the next person in line-and he acted as though I was not even there.

Well, after the blond had gotten her beer he deigned to serve me.

But it kind of ruined the experience for me. Who knew-being invisible is actually kind of unpleasant.
author: Sue C.

description: The Page is a small, divey bar. It definitely seems like it's a place with regulars. The bartender was pretty cool. I ended up just ordering the Ommegang White. They have a decent beer selection that rotates often. They also have a pool table and TVs. A nice place to go to to get away from the busyness of Haight St.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
If you were to look up "Dive Bar" in the dictionary, you would find a nice big picture of The Page and nothing else. This is quite simply the divey-est place imaginable, and I'm a big fan.

This place is very straightforward, so my review will be the same. Here is everything you need to know:

-Good beer.
-CASH ONLY. So bring cash.
-Don't complain about it being cash only. No one wants to hear you whine.
-Not a place to rage. Come here to kickback, drink beer, and talk to your friends. 
-On Friday nights the front bar-area gets crowded, so your best chance to find a place to sit will be the downstairs area in the back. 
-Pool and fooseball tables are downstairs as well.

That's it. Appreciate this place for what it is, and what it isn't.
author: Brian S.

description:
Again, I'm out without drinking. Still, having a good time

Pros
Nice atmosphere/decor
Multiple pool tables
Friendly staff
Fresh water

Cons 
Cash only 
Fake bookshelf (and I love books)
author: Rishikesh T.

description: Divey bar. Got here on a Saturday night and was lucky to score a couple seats as these girls were leaving. Drinks are not expensive here compared to other places. I have to say though I don't understand why bars have drinks that are like 6.50. Can you just make it 6 or 7? Although, quarters for laundry. Not horrible. :) I'd come back here. Good relaxing, casual, divey bar.
author: Julie L.

description:
Great neighborhood spot in the Lower Haight. We stayed a block away and finally stopped in for a drink on one of our last days in town. We happened to walk in during the very end of the Raiders-Niners game on a Sunday afternoon, which was a lot of fun to watch (although not for the Niners fans at the bar).

The crowd seemed to mostly be made up of friendly local folks and we had some great conversations with one of the more diverse crowds we saw in the city. I forget the bartenders name but she was super friendly and an old childhood friend of a guy we were sitting next to. The place felt like a pleasant, tight-knit community.

Beer is pretty cheap and they have a solid selection of beers on tap. It's definitely a dive, but an authentic one...not a super-contrived hipster slum that will still charge you $7 for a beer. 

We returned the night before we flew out and enjoyed the nighttime crowd just the same. I'll definitely be back on my next visit to the city!
author: Tyler B.

description: Reasonable prices and pool in a brick-clad subterranean quadrant; enough said.
author: Wendell A.

description:
Excellent beer selection.
Great happy hour prices.
Bad lighting.
Carpet.
Comfy yet torn up chairs.
Pool table.
Yep, this place screams me.

Cash only.
author: Karen C.

description:
I've ran by this bar numerous times in the day and always wanted to check it out. Finally got the opportunity this past weekend and was really into the vibe of the place. Good beer selection and a really relaxed area in the back.

My friends and I sat down in this little nook next to the stairs. The room was decked out with fake brick walls and a fake library panel. There was also a little magazine/book stand with some selections I really appreciated. Any bar with the Aeneid on hand gets an automatic 3 stars for that alone.

I'll definitely come back soon, but will probably try to stay away 9pm and later. At this time, the music distinctly changed from palatable classic and indie rock tunes to current pop/r&b songs. This leads me to believe the crowd starts to get a bit too bro-y in the evenings.
author: Jon T.

description:
It's a cute "divey" neighborhood meet up bar, with nice bartenders and a whole bunch of hipsters. Used to be called "Chances" some time ago, a sleepier place if I recall...
Usually I have ended up here as going on the way to someplace else or after having been brought by someone else. 
However, they do offer many bottles of standard fare American and Imported beer, and you might even recognize some tunes on their sound system.
They also have a pool table.
author: Rachel D.

description: 5 stars for hosting the awesome Northern California Family Dog Rescue Pints for Pups last night!!!  They also let me try several of the beers before committing which was super cool of them!
author: Poochie M.

description: The Page always makes me feel comfortable. Live music and a solid tap selection only contribute to the good times. Easily five stars.
author: Szymon N.

description:
The page is just one of those neighborhood staples. It's dark, it's dingy, and the decor is out of date, but these are all qualities that add to its awesomeness. They cover the basics well and have a good selection of beers. 

This place is popular, so you can find a decent crowd here most nights of the week. It can get a bit tough to find seats on weekends, but if you are persistent there are some pretty cozy little chairs around tiny tables that you can actually squeeze a ton of friends around if you really try. Lap sitting may be necessary but that is all part of the charm! 

There is a pool table. It is in the lower area of the bar where it tends to be a little less crowded. Seek refuge here on if you are claustrophobic and you come on a Friday night.
author: Jena M.

description: Dark and crowded on a Friday night...smells of stale cigarette smoke, has any cocktail, beer or wine you could want and complete with deer heads and a pool table. Perfect typical hangout bar. Not a ton of seating but standing room down near the back room. Cash only.
author: Ashley M.

description:
IsHey girl 
Thank you for coming Tonight 
Simbell cant find her cigarettes 
Menthol.
Did you take them by mistake ? 
She asked me to ask you
author: Brand B.

description:
We went in on a Friday night and paid 5 bucks because there was a DJ. It was super crowded and it was hard to get a read on the vibe of the place. We wanted to dance but there just wasn't room - people were just kind of clumped together with the occasional shove as someone needed to blaze a path through. Maybe the DJ was popular and that was the reason for the over-crowdedness(??) - no clue.
The bar staff didn't seem too interested that we were thirsty but we ended up with our canned beer. But I get it, it was a Friday night. 
Expect it to be crowded and expect it to be hard to get a drink. I'll go back on a different day of the week.
author: Kevin F.

description: You can avoid SF drink prices while still getting the SF vibe. Was pleasantly surprised to discover a beer was 6-7 bucks. ATM in the back and a pool table. Close to Haight bars and Divisadero bars. A good weekday place.
author: Kevin K.

description:
This place felt a little weird and dirty to me. Maybe it's because the lighting was horrible or because I felt like I had vertigo because the floor was uneven, but I was claustrophobic and uncomfortable the whole time we were here. The bathroom was a dirty closet and I felt sufficiently creeped out in there. The service was OK. We had a large group trying to order a laundry list of items, so it didn't help that people weren't quite on the same page when it came time to order, but the bartender could have been a little nicer. 

Though I feel like the place has great potential as a cool hole in the wall bar, I couldn't see myself coming here again. 

Also, keep in mind that it's cash only!
author: Kaitlin D.
Brian J.

description:
Chill neighborhood bar with some good beers on tap. 

9 times out of 10 the bar service is good, one time we had to wait 5 minutes while the bar lady hung out with her friend at the end of the bar.

You can usually get a seat here on a weekday and the pool tables aren't hard to get a game on.

If you want a break from some of the trendier or diveyier bars on Divis, definitely check this place out.
author: Cali J.

description:
I'm feelin this place. 
Great atmosphere, vibe & bartenders. 
The pool table is a huge plus. 
Great mix of SF culture.
Solo, on a date, or with the homies, this watering hole is gold.
author: Louie L.

description:
I have been here more than a few times since moved to the area in summer 2011, and this is my favorite local bar. 

I can always count on a relaxing atmosphere, great beer and whiskey selections, and friendly bartenders.
author: Aaron S.

description:
This and fly bar are my two favorites in the area. The Page has pretty great drink deals like $8.50 for a pint of old speckled hen and a shot of bushmills is solid.

More importantly $5 Pliny the Elder rocks my everything. Hard.
author: Misha T.

description: Great dive bar in the heart of the new Divisadero corridor. Pool tables that don't have hour-long waits, cozy tables for two, friendly bartenders and affordable drinks. For these reasons, I'd give The Page 4 stars, but to really enjoy it make sure you go on a night when you're looking for a cozy, local spot - not a classy, sophisticated wine bar where you'll be forces to choose between a 2009 and 2009 Syrah.
author: Erin W.

description: Didn't spend much time here, but loved the vibe on a Monday night. Road up with a friend on our motorcycles and grabbed a Death & Taxes. Sat in the back near the pool table and enjoyed a chat surrounded by strange lamps, books and stuffed animal heads (not my thing in general, but it worked in this case.) It's dark and kind of dive bar-esque, which I do love. Heard it's crazy on the weekends, but Monday was super chill. I'll be back for sure.
author: Chantill L.

description:
I have a very specific checklist for bars that become 'my favorite' in some capacity.

This is that check list:

- Divey
- Cheap drinks
- Decent Happy Hour
- Good jukebox
- Carpeting
- On my block

Yeah the bartenders can be kind of bitchy sometimes (sometimes they're nice!) and the crowd can definitely be eclectic (i.e. hit or miss)... and it can get hella crowded on the weekends... but none of those things are on my checklist (damn that rigid checklist!)... plus carpeting and proximity get me every time.
author: Jake D.

description: Dropped by for an Ommegang Glimmerglass saison. That's all.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I love this bar! No frills and always a thrill. I always appreciate the laid back vibe in there, it's one of my favorite simple dive bars in the area.

2 Pool tables and lots of seating. Pretty decent selection of beers on tap. Can't go wrong.
author: Caitlin F.

description: The BEST! A very good beer selection, not the best, but they get some great ones! Sadly they still must offer PBR+ for the douche hipsterbag, that thinks it's cool to drink swill. All the bartenders are great, nice cozy place. Best bar I've found in SF. Of course Toronado is better for beer if you want to be treated like shit.
author: Charles K.

description: Yup. Dig this place. The guy and I do our best friending here on the down time and good place to introduce to my gals.
author: Netta W.

description:
I'm pretty sure they were over capacity. And violating a fire code. And with that many people crammed inside, it might actually drive business away, not encourage people to stay. Not that I would know anything about fire codes. Or running a bar. 

OH WAIT- I'm a lawyer in training AND I was a bartender. Well, f. me. 

The end of the night was a drag due to the overcrowding and the cash only and the high prices. It could have been so good. But it totally wasn't.
author: Emily D.

description:
Visited The Page for the first time a couple of weeks ago when I was visiting some friends. This place is pretty cool, and I look forward to coming back. It's not super trendy or fancy, but not a dive of all dives, either. Cash only, so come prepared. It was pretty crowded when we got there, but there appeared to be a good number of smaller tables and chairs along the wall of windows (which would have been ideal to snag) and a back room with a pool table. We just stuck to the far end of the bar and lucked out when a couple of people left their seats. 

Bartenders were all pretty friendly and the drinks were well made (no skimping on the alcohol) and reasonably priced. My friend's husband was excited about a couple of the beers they had available. 

Extra star for the cool electronic jukebox!
author: Amanda F.

description: Great neighborhood dive bar. Awesome spot for cheap beers and a game of pool. Be advised that it is cash-only!
author: Tanner S.

description: I met the love of my life at this bar one night.  Her name was Chelsea and she had flaxen blonde hair and green eyes.  We talked about traveling the world together, loved all the same movies, and both had a deep affection for 17th century french poetry.... As the bar closed I couldnt find her.  In her place was an old half blind man named Guss and his mangy dog who kept sniffing my crouch.  Guss kept patting me on the head and saying "he couldnt believe he was talking to the king of Spain!".... I honestly have no idea what happened that night!  Also had a great burrito next door and brought it back into the bar.  That was cool too.
author: Peter M.

description: Perfectly divey, cheap drinks, pool and foosball. Cash only - at least you won't forget to close out your tab after one too many.
author: Laura M.

description:
The drinks.
They were cleaning out the beer pipes so all beers on tap except 2 or 3 were available. $5 for beer.

The service.
Everyone was served and I sware the bartender looked at twice and still.didn't say anything. Even the guy next to me at the bar said something.

The people.
Interesting crowd. Very diverse. 

The bar.
Very dark. Nice big red man chairs. Looks like old men sit there with cigars and a glass of scotch. Pool table with a weird portrait of a man hanging above. 

Would I come back?
Yes it was a interesting bar. Great place to people watch.
author: Aleena N.

description: Favorite go-to neighborhood bar. Solid beer selection, chill crowd, comfortable. Also, a super friendly staff that doesn't mind a mid-60's to early 70's playlist on the jukebox.
author: Eric M.

description:
I've heard a lot of good things about The Page, but my single visit there was short and relatively disappointing.  The decor was cute, and the beer selection looked decent.

The bar was extremely crowded (I believe I was visiting on a Saturday night after dinner), though, and the patrons were a little younger and a lot drunker than I expected for that time of night.

I ended up getting pushed down to seats by the pool table, where I spent the evening dodging pool cues and hipster butts.  Oh well.

I would definitely give The Page another shot, though.
author: Bill H.

description:
The Page is definitely your go-to neighborhood bar. Everyone is really friendly and laid back and it's an casual and chill spot to grab a drink.

I've been here a few times and can say that it's a solid spot for happy hour or to wind down at the end of the night. They have a wide selection of beer on tap and they are all pretty cheap. Howerver, they're cash only so remember to grab some cash ahead of time.

There's tons of tables and seats at the bar so it's the perfect spot for a group. There's also a pool table in the back.  

If you're looking for a casual, laid back, no frills kinda place to grab a drink, The Page is definitely it.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Cool neighborhood bar. I was shocked to find that it was pretty crowded on a Thursday night. Not so crowded that you can't hear the person you're standing next to, but crowded enough so that you're not wondering whether they failed a health inspection. All of the ingredients for a good, chill bar: cheap drinks, friendly people, enough seats, and pool tables (if you're into that)
author: Mike W.

description: A great local bar, and a neighborhood classic.  My parents went to this bar with their friends (though it had another name then) in the 60s and 70s.  Bartenders are always friendly, and there is a wonderful old den/cocktail lounge vibe.  I recently hosted a fundraiser/birthday party here (with 10% of the total bar tab, not just our party's, going to a favorite non-profit).  Working with the manager, Bob, was a piece of cake, and my event went off without a hitch.  I also always meet friendly neighborhood folks here.
author: Aileen J.

description: Great local dive bar, someone I work with brought me in and he knew everyone there (lived right there). Very nice staff, reasonable drinks, and a busy place with nice patrons. The neighborhood was amusing as well, I would come back.
author: Jonah K.

description:
"Daddy, these arm chairs smell like grandpa."
"That's the smell of broken dreams, son."

And Budweiser...but mostly broken dreams.
author: Michael D.

description:
You know what?  I was pretty messed up by the time I entered The Page, and I STILL didn't like the vibe I got from that place.

I really like the dive-y interior, but the clientele was just so-so. 

At least they had my favorite scotch.  
One shot of Laprohaig and I bolted out that door.
author: Samantha P.

description:
after going to a couple other places in san francisco, i've still been dying to come back here.

why are the selections of beer in bars in sf so bad?  so many more beers on tap here.

i want to come back here so i can have my magic hat #9...

if anyone can recommend where i can get an ipa that's not lagunitas in sf, let me know!!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Great: Foosball!!!  (When I can get someone to play with me!)

Fair: The drinks and service - can be hit-or-miss in the 'tude department

Poor: Getting carded multiple times on the same night by the same bar-tender. . . or wait, are you just hitting on me?  Cause while my crows' feet sure appreciate the fatuous compliment, my aging intellect does not.

A "meh" bar when it was Chances, and an "A-OK" bar as The Page.  We come here for after-work happy hour from time to time and it suits us just fine.

Foosball anyone?  
What's that?  Afraid of my 19-year-old spunk?

Wait, what?
author: Ravena F.

description: Seems like it's become a bro bar and there are some bartenders that are unfriendly. Rotating the taps a bit more would also be helpful. I miss when The Page was awesome.
author: Cori W.

description:
The Page is a great sorta-divey neighborhood bar.

They have a really large selection of whiskeys (apparently it's the owner's thing) and there's usually a whiskey of the night that's $5/shot. Give it a try! If whiskey isn't your thing, they're well stocked with everything else, including craft beer.

Happy hour runs until 7 daily and is $1 off everything, making that whiskey even more attractive.

Cash only, but they have an ATM (beware the fee unless you have a bank that refunds them!).

Staff is very friendly and attentive; I didn't wait longer than a few minutes after coming up to the bar to get a drink.

Seating is a little scarce (there are tables along the outside wall and a few down by the second pool table in the back) but there's enough standing room that it doesn't feel too crowded.

Music comes from a jukebox, so you'll hear whatever your fellow patrons want to listen to. (Read the FAQ on the website to see what's frowned upon. *cough*Phish*cough*)

No food, but they're fine with people bringing in stuff from nearby restaurants (I recommend Little Chihuhua. Best drunken nachos ever.) which is good if you're like me and fail to eat before losing track of how many drinks you've had.

A bit farther from my house than I usually walk, but whatever, it's worth the trip. Stop in if you're in the neighborhood and I just might be there sampling the whiskey.
author: Sam K.

description:
Go elsewhere if you can

I could rant but I don't have the time

1. Rude bartender
2. Bad drinks
3. Rude entitled patrons - hey jackhole, I'm a local too but it doesn't MATTER! We all deserve equal treatment
author: Rachel O.

description: For a long time, I felt like my every visit to The Page was going to be punctuated by a punch to the face from the bartender's Irish boyfriend. I don't know if that bartender still works there, or what her boyfriend's problem was, but I've since outgrown that notion, and have gone on to pass one or two enjoyable drunken evenings there. On my last visit, I really noticed how young and single the vibe was. I seem to remember a slightly more diverse scene reflecting the neighborhood demographic, but that's San Francisco for you, always changing. Still, I'd generally rather be kissed on than punched. Depending.
author: Joe V.

description:
This is where plaid goes to drink.

Literally, like 10 plaid shirts---and by that I don't mean lumberjacks-- where sitting at and around the bar.

WHEN DID PLAID BECOME HIP? (I must have missed that day in fashion police academy when they said NOT to arrest 20 somethings who are trying to look rustic who clearly have never picked up an ax before).

Anyway, beside the horrid fashion, (and honestly, it wasn't' just the men) the drinks were as cheap as the hookers in the TL (I'm assuming) and as stiff as the 'Frisco wind that night.


Bring cash. You'll need it since it's the only thing they accept.

Great place to chill...but it's louder than the outfits people wear there.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Oh, The Page.

I've spent many evenings here. It's my favorite little spot in Lower Haight because 1.) foosball, .2) pool tables, and 3.) the carpet. I can't tell you how many times I've discretely spilled beer on accident and no one ever noticed the wet spots on the floor. Brilliant. I can keep my classy lady reputation.
author: Mary Anne R.

description:
Pretentious locals (including myself): Check 

Small, but thought out beer selection on tap: Check

Pool Tables and Foosball: Check

Awesome bartenders: Check

Great Jukebox: Check

Bizarre taxidermy: Check

Man this bar has everything I love! Being in the neighborhood helps too. Everyone that works there is great and nice as long as you aren't a jerk to them. Yes we all know on busy nights it might take a while to get your drink, but that doesn't give you a free pass to be a jerk. I'm looking at you USF kids!

Crowd can be very diverse especially on the weekends. Ranges from Mission hipster to Marina douche.

One note. It's not the best place to bring a party of more than 3 people since seating can be extremely difficult.
author: Alex E.

description:
I stopped by this bar on my way to another bar. The drink selection is good, and prices great (I got my rum and coke for $4 and it wasn't happy hour). Good decor. The bar felt boat-like to me which I liked. 

It was super crowded (this was Friday night) but luckily we got seats. Without seats, you have to stand in a tight space and constantly move for people trying to squeeze through - not worth it as a hang out in my opinion. But if you find seats, or are there when its not crowded, or just want a cheap drink on your way to something else: a very good find.
author: Mia M.

description:
Cheap pool tables. Decent happy hour. So so bartenders. Terrible music - in the way too obvious alterna-indie-crap - genre on the jukebox most of the time (but it is an internet one so you can DL new tunes. Sidenote: they only have the censored version of "Straight Outta Compton." WTF is that?). They have a whiskey of the week which is nice.

It was better when it was Chances, but it'll do for cheap pool and beer. Decent brew selection.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Cool space to hang out with your friends, but that's about it. There's a pool table and foosball table in the back and lots of nooks and crannies to hang out in, but other than that, there's not a whole lot going on. Just your average bar.
author: Leana L.

description:
I love the Page when it's empty and HATE it when it's full.  
If you can secure a table, I recommend it.  The Page has a great back space (decorated like some crazy Grandpa's hunting room) with a pool table and extra seating.

The bartenders are usually pretty indifferent, which I appreciate.  They make their Margarita's from mix, which I don't like, but they were $5 bucks during happy hour so I'll take it.

On a busy night (Thurs-Sat) be prepared to wait a while for your drink, and then lose most of it while bumping into others on your way back to your group.  Always a good time!

It's located near lots of buses and close to the Indy.  We sometimes like to pop in before shows, which is nice.  Check this place out if you are ever in the area.
author: Carmel U.

description:
Hey what's up PAGE!!!

I have been going here for quite some time, most of the times, you know, you might not be like all good, like a little bit tipsy or just straight up hammered, same thing , right!?

I just wanted to say that this bar is awesome, period.
If you don't thinks so, you are probably sober.
People tend to get really drunk here......

Anyhow, short and sweet.
Really nice bartenders, door guys and beer selection.
The jukebox sucks, sorry.

But I am always back for more.

Sniff ya later Page!
author: cecilia k.

description: Great dive bar! Cozy, slightly busy on a Wednesday night. Includes a pool table, and plenty of nooks and crannies to squeeze yourself into. Plenty of beer on tap, including a cider! I loved it here!
author: Karina H.

description:
I love The Page for multiple reasons:

It's cozy. 

Close.

Great music.

You can play fooz-ball and pool. 

Their bathrooms have the best cute-check mirror ever.

They have quality matches.

They serve strong drinks (though not exactly cheap)

I feel comfortable coming by myself.

I can watch Simpsons with subtitles.
author: Jessica T.

description: $5 for Pliny the elder pints. Nice location. I didn't know it extended to the back with another pool table and foosball. Stools and nice seating. Apparently it's cash only but has an ATM. I'll come again!
author: Marty J.

description:
The Page has a lot of potential.

The inside is rad, it feels a lot like the Red Room in Santa Cruz, except it's got a pool table, you can't smoke, and the jukebox sucks. 

Definitely my favorite bar on Divis, but I'm taking off a star for not giving my girlfriend a free drink on her 21st birthday. Isn't that standard?
author: Murphy O.

description: The best part was when the bouncer knocked half of my drink onto the floor and my friends, and then got in my face about it with his eyes all unfocused and bleary.
author: Andrew J.

description:
I'd passed by this place more than once and dismissed it as nothing special until I'd finally clued in to the beer selection.  Craft beer, and a fine selection thereof (read: Belgians, wonderful Belgians), on tap or in bottles for your enjoyment.

To be fair, The Page is no major destination like Toronado or Beer Revolution, but for those in the vicinity who show up at the right time (late afternoon pint-lifting is favored, the place is barely manageable crowd-wise on a Saturday evening) this place is a gem.  Also contains a full bar with other drinks for the beer-disinclined.

Lastly, there is also a schmaltzy fabric 'painting' of a deer on the wall that requires your reverence and appreciation.  

 Go forth and worship, pint in hand.
author: Eric P.

description:
I've actually moved 2 blocks away from The Page since my last review.

Sure, it's within walking distance from my apartment and that completely changed my opinion about it. It comes in handy when my liquor cabinet at home is running low and I'm feeling thirsty. On a cold winter night, I don't want to trek more then 3 blocks to grab a drink. Convenience factor = 5 extra points.

The Page has now become my neighborhood bar. I've never watched Cheers, and I don't even know the entire theme song, but when they say, "Where everybody knows your nameee..." I assume they're talking about me and my relationship with The Page.

Drinks are moderately price, my favorite bartender Charlie (shoutout!) knows I need a gin 'n' tonic the second I walk in, and their shitty/old/shady foosball table has grown on me. The crowd is a good mix. And who doesn't love a short stumble home?
author: Michelle N.

description:
Last summer, me and my roommates came here every Monday for about 3 weeks and tried to teach ourselves how to play pool.

We sucked soooo bad.

Luckily, the atmosphere during the week is laidback enough so that the other patrons waiting for us to finish our 40-minute games didn't seem to mind. On the weekend, however, the place is another story, overrun with hipsters that may have took a wrong turn through the Castro and ended up here instead of the Mission. Divis is turning into Valencia's twin, I swear!

The main perks of the place? The digital jukebox, 2 pool tables, foozeball table, and the facade of a creaky old bookcase and fake flickering candle in the back that remind me of the Haunted Mansion in Disneyland. Oh, and that little nook near the men's bathroom with enough room for just 2, so that you can chill a bit away from the crowd and admire yourself (or your date) in the mirror above the counter.

There's not much to dislike... it's really a nicer, more spacious version of your typical local dive. I guess I could do without the preserved mountain lion thing and the mooseheads hovering up above, but other than that, this place is great!
author: Kate V.

description: Love this place - accidentally came across it last year wandering back from Haight and revisited last night, great atmosphere! Nice staff, nice drinks and a pool table out the back to keep the boys occupied!
author: Tracy O.

description:
It's hard finding nice bartenders and door staff at hip bars in San Francisco. I'm still reeling from a geeky adolscense and I often don't feel cool enough in a lot of places in the City.

I had an experience last night at The Page that reminded me just how good it feels when you encounter a friendly staff on a night out.

I went to the Page for drinks with a friend and we had a fine time enjoying the abundance of cute little hipster males in the place. As she took off, I went outside to my parked Vespa to ride home. To my dismay, I actually watched myself, in slow-motion, lock my keys in the storage compartment of my scooter along with my cell phone, wallet, and house keys. It was 12:30 in the morning. I had no cash in my pocked. I was a few miles from my house and I couldn't remember anyones number.

Garrett, the door guy, tried to help me pop the lock. When he couldn't get it, he borrowed the bartenders cell phone to call me a locksmith. We waited for a bit and then Garrett suggested that he cancel the locksmith, who was going to cost $200, and try to get home to wake up my roommate to get my spare key. He even offered me bus fare for Muni! I realized that he was right and it was probably cheaper to take a cab to home, grab the key, take a cab back, and then grab my scoot. I did just that. It saved me a lot of money and a lot of time waiting in the middle of the night.

So thanks to Garrett and the rest of the helpful and hip patrons and staff of the Page! You made this moron's night a little easier to contend with!
author: Veronica L.

description: "Cheap" George T. Stagg Bourbon
author: Jared C.

description: Should I like you or not like you? You teeter me on ruination. You make me feel claustrophobic but I feel subservient to a weird masochistic beating by sitting there, taking your surly ways, and flinging my ideas off your walls -- all the way to wanting to try to play two games of pool on the two different tables at the same time. When considering the difficult questions in life: the chicken or the egg, the olive or the gin, the yelper or Yelp, The Page solves one of them, at least: Gorgeous Men in Flannel before The Page. Dare I feel inferior amongst you? Nigh! You embolden my goal to never wear patterns in San Francisco. And that's why I like you.
author: Jon A.

description:
The page is great - amazing beer selection...lost abbey, Russian river etc. And pool and bad ass taxidermied animals and super reasonable prices...what more do you want?

And by the way to the previous reviewer, I AM a bartender and a hot toddy IS whiskey, water and lemon juice, sometimes people confuse toddies with hot buttered brandy and rum but that's your problem, not the Page's
author: Ben B.

description:
So my friend offered his house for my birthday party on a Sunday afternoon. It was margaritas and Mexican night and we had a few too many margs, amongst 10 of us, and by 9:00 pm we decided to head down the hill to The Page.

We should not have been served. Any of us. We were face down ass up, tore up from the floor up, just a bunch of drunken maniacs. So from 9pm - 1am, according to the times on my pictures, we continued to suck down cocktails and nonstop shots of Jagermeister, play pool, harass all the locals, the poor sweet bartender gal, and I even got a free drink at midnight. 

5 stars for serving all of us blacked out alcoholics for 4 hours!!!
author: Braden B.

description: The Page was fantastic!  We had a birthday/fundraiser for our nonprofit at the bar and Bob was extremely friendly and open to the idea!  It was my first time there.  The beer selection was fantastic and the staff terrific.  It is cash only, but it wasn't a problem since they had a cash machine on the premises.  I will continue to promote and support The Page whenever in San Francisco.  Thanks Bob and The Page!  Flowering Hope
author: Flowering Hope O.

description:
An awesomely mellow bar that has comfy tables and chairs for you and your friends to take over for the week's latest rendezvous. It's very chill, the people are nice, and it's a fav. Points for the Arrogant Bastard on tap, a total tribute to my san marcos-ian past.

Also a plus, my single girlfriends tell me they usually meet men here.
author: Nikki M.

description:
One of my most favorite neighborhood bars!  This place is easily within walking distance from my house, the vibe is very laid back and mellow, there is plenty of room to sit down or head to the back to play some bar games, and you are always sure to meet someone new every time you go there.  I love this place as somewhere to start the night, to stop in for last call or to just spend all evening there with friends.  

The staff is great and friendly, especially the dirty blonde gentleman checking ID's, and the bartenders are attentive and quick, not to mention fun! Drinks are pretty inexpensive and never lacking a strong taste. If I could go here every night and make it seem like I do not have a problem, I would!
author: Alexa V.

description: Five stars for the beer selection. Often as good as Toronado. In weekend and later evenings it can get jammed up with a crowd I don't care much for. This was my go to after work spot when I lived here.
author: Eric W.

description:
Taxidermy, a narrow hall, pool tables,foos ball tables, beer, wine and lots of young people on a Saturday night pounding back drinks. That's The Page (and other bars in the lower Haight). 

The bouncer and patrons hanging outside the door paid my friends and me a great compliment while carding us. They were playing "guess how old these old guys are". They all guessed that we were born in the 70s. Thank you very much, I'll buy you guys beer later (we were all in our late 40s and I'm in my 50s).

Good choice of beer at the pub. We had IPA of some sort then I moved on and tried Sierra Nevada, Glissade. This is a bock beer, I suppose it is of the traditional pale bocks of Germany. A little too malty for me, but when you're getting elbowed by so many people, it didn't matter.

Move down further into the dark hall, and go down the stairs and you'll see an additional pool table and good luck trying to find a place to squish in. This place reminds of my college days and our student union building. Look up and you'll find a multi-point trophy buck deer head mount staring right back at you. ~ Dorfman! What kind of man hits a defenseless animal? 

Great place to hang out.
author: Reyz A.

description: The Page is the most authentic "neighborhood bar" I've found in this city.  Great laid back atmosphere, personable/friendly bar staff, great beer selection, and a superb selection of bourbons and whiskies.  For hanging out after work, there is no better option in the area, but sadly once it gets later this place gets filled to capacity with amateur douchebags, marina kids, and the B&T crowd who apparently has never been told how to act in a bar.  It's these cretins who I suspect have written some of the more negative reviews below, so if you know how to act ignore those reviews and stop by for a pint or three sometime after work.  You'll be glad you did.  If you're looking for hella shots of jager "bra" and will get huffy when they tell you it's cash only, please do us all a favor and return to the marina or polk street where you'll be more at home.
author: Joshua W.

description:
My guy friends always want to go here - the foos ball table is the draw.  And what a draw it is.  They inevitably play foos, get pretty drunk and I wonder why I came here.

For me, it's generally too crowded and I've never had a drink I liked here.  At a regular bar, I always order my regular drink - vodka soda.  I'm not particular about my vodka (really), unless I'm feeling fancypants.  Everytime I order that drink at The Page, it tastes like a gin and soda.  I can only assume it's the particular variety of cheap vodka they use (and I'm all about cheap).  So I've remedied that by choosing beer, but I wish I didn't have to.

Anyhow - The Page is cool for a place to meet up or a place to end up, but not my ideal spot.
author: Mac M.

description:
I was a good solid fan of the Page, maybe because its one block from where I live but this weekend it all changed.  The Page during the week, 4 stars; the Page on a Saturday 2-3.  

The Page's beer selection reads like an indie record.  Recently I drank a 3-star beer from Kenya and some super delicious Belgian beer.  The beers and relaxed weekday crowd is worthy of 4 stars but alas the weekend ruins it....

This past Saturday I walked in to some crowded, weird college singles party.  In the back was a man who looked like the Geico cave man, which isn't a problem per se, I think they are cute.  What was a problem was the two guys in the front corner who looked like skin heads straight out of American History X.   I know, don't judge a book by its cover but perhaps they may want to reconsider bic'ing their head and all black army style wardrobe.  Isn't the most friendly outfit.  Even so they aren't the reason for 3 stars, it was the collective group.

Sorry Page I do want you to succeed with your foosball table, so just go during the week, unless you like the college cool kids party then Page away on the weekend!

ps.  It's cash only.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
My roommates have deemed The Page "the last resort" if your quest to makeout has failed over the course of the evening.  I wouldn't necessarily agree....because no one in here is smiling.  Over the foosball table, brows are furied in concentration.  Artsy dames lurk in the corner, scowling out at the crowd.  I cannot tell you how many eye rolls I've received when trying to strike up a conversation with dudes at this bar.  Look, I know your childhood in upper-middle class Marin must have been a doozey and you are compensating by living the Bohemian life in the big bad City, but could you at least TRY to be polite?  

You can't win 'em all and I'm not gonna knock The Page just because I strike out here consistently.  The vibe can be described as "stoner-mellow" and if your night is on the verge of teetering towards sleepy-time you might pass out in your chair here.  The bar itself is pretty rad though...tons of old, funky detail, tasteful, vintage furnishings, and a pretty solid beer selection.  Would recommend it to meet someone for a quiet drink, but wouldn't plan the whole night around it.
author: Kerry D.

description:
I have only been here once, but I'll give you the low-down from what I know.

Cash Only. Good to know. They have wine, but I realized this is really more of a beer drinking place, as you get pushed, kicked, and knocked around all over. There's never a safe place to stand as people are always trying to get by.

Pool tables in the back... cool.

Very long and narrow space with a diverse crowd. I'd come back, but it probably won't be at the top of my list.
author: Ashley D.

description: It's big, it's cozy, it's comfortable, it's easy to get a seat, it's got two pool tables and a foosball table, the nicest bartenders, tons of beer on tap, generous pours, a motley crew of barflies, and a cheap jukebox. What more do you need?
author: Anna H.

description:
This place is a quintessential dive - the way a dive should be. Lots of beers (incl my fave, double chocolate stout). Red leather chairs. A digital jukebox. A combination of hipsters and frat boys.  No tourists.

Layla the bartender rocks!
author: Andrew K.

description: The place smelled very strongly of urine in the main rooms while we were there last week during the early evening... Very off-putting.
author: Brittany L.

description: A good crowd can usually be found here but the place is starting to look pretty shabby and worn.
author: Rita A.

description:
This was usually a hit but at times a miss. 

They had a great selection of beers on tap, but when it was a miss I would call it a brocation--a bratwurstfest. The pool table is available for you hustlers and as a make-out stool when the bar is full--seen it plenty of times!

 I miss you SF but keep a page open for me when I arrive, and soak it with the urine stench I'm familiar with!
author: Ishmael V.

description:
I'm a little sad to have to write this review.  I live in western addition, have been there for 5+ years.  The Page has been a mainstay for me while here.  

Last night I was there with a friend and a work client.  We were at NOPA for dinner before, then headed to The Page for some drinks.

We were immediately snubbed by the two bartenders, for reasons I cannot explain.  We were friendly, talkative, but not annoying.  However, we must not have ranked high enough on the cool scale. 

We had a couple drinks and then the bartender proceeded to cut me off.  I was a little shocked, as I had about 4 beers and a shot.  I don't consider myself a lightweight, but maybe I need to self evaluate.

I'm not trying to hate on The Page, as I think it's probably the best bar in the neighborhood.  However, the bartenders are a bit questionable.  I get that it's a cool part of town and they need to come across as being sort of hip, but the whole 'I don't care about anything, dress like a slob and I'm cooler than you thing' is a little much.  If need be, I can watch the Star Wars trilogy and brush up on my Sci-Fi knowledge, just post a disclaimer at the door.  Plus, the bartender had some boyfriend-type kicking it at the bar while she worked...He tried to get involved once I was 'cut-off', which I didn't appreciate.  When I follow my wife to work and loiter, I at least stay out of her affairs.  Maybe you should do the same.  

In conclusion, The Page is dope, but the bartenders are whack.
author: Tony M.

description:
I'm gonna go ahead and give The Page 4 stars. The girls running the bar Thursday (4/7) night were effing awesome. Super sweet, super cute, very fast! And accurate with their mixes! Not too strong/not to weak of drinks. 

This bar is a diver, but not nasty- at least not when I went. I have only been here one time. I will say, a round of beers/shots (for 4 people) cost $40- woof! If you think about it and break it down to 8 drinks, I suppose that's standard. (The bars I'm used to going to LA don't charge that much, but then again, this is an expensive city.)

I had a really good time, got pretty drunk, but all in all, glad we finished our night at The Page.

*We got a super sweet and badass cab driver right outside which is like, UNHEARD OF for us... so maybe this is the right neighborhood to be going out in.
author: Savannah P.

description: Neighborhood bar. They have pool tables and foosball which is always a plus. It can get really crowded at times. The crowd can be hit or miss. Sometimes people run the jukebox that shouldn't. Cash only which is always a bummer.
author: Raul R.

description:
I'm a big fan of The Page!  It's the definition of a dive bar... very relaxed and chill atmosphere.  It doesn't look like they've changed the décor in 50 years, but it works.

They always have a variety of good beers on tap and the bartenders are pleasant.  If you are in the area and you're looking to unwind, socialize, and drink good beer, check out The Page.
author: Kristen M.

description:
The bar itself is rad. I totally dig it, and when i'm in the area i stop in, or if i'm meeting someone from across town i suggest this as a halfway spot. The selection of beer isn't small!

But on a cold night, i like an irish coffee or a hot toddy. The irish coffees i got had too much whiskey (yes, folks, there is such a thing), and were lukewarm at best. There was barely any coffee in them (i got a couple, hoping there would be some improvement with the second--there wasn't), too much booze, and the cream wasn't frothed or floated on top, just poured right in. It was a mess. The hot toddy was only slightly better, though just slightly. It had less booze and was hot, but it was basically hot lemon water with whiskey(?), and a slice of lemon with some cloves stuck in it.

Long story short: I like The Page. I do. I like beer, i promise. But i like hot drinks, and this place could not make them right. I'll be back for the beer.
author: Phuong M.

description:
Good local's bar for a chill night with friends.  

Good beer, cheap drinks and a friendly crowd : )

The service was fast even when busy and it was easy to find a couple of seats...also,  2 pool tables and a foosball table as well. 

Overall, I had a great time, although if you're looking for a crazy, trendy scene this is definitely NOT the place. It's very much casual but a nice break on a weeknight.
author: Emilee G.

description: Very fun place to hang out.  Reasonably priced drinks, pool tables, a foosball table, and a great vibe.
author: John M.

description:
"What are you two ladies doing in a dive bar like The Page?"

Long pause wherein my friend and I exchange awkward glances and in sync respond in the only way we know how: "Drinking?"

The Page is pure class. I thoroughly enjoy the roaring bobcat and other such taxidermy and the general congeniality of the atmosphere. It gets pretty cozy in here, so you are bound to make a new friend or to annoy somebody who is playing pool because you are standing in their way ("No really, I don't mind if you jab my eye out with your pool stick!" [that's what she said] {somebody stop me now because now my asides are having asides and things could get pretty meta if nobody intervenes}). There is also a little make-out nook behind the bathrooms that has always been occupied when I am there but it looks awesome and reminiscent of a confessional. 

A staple in my bar hopping repertoire.
author: Rachael S.

description:
This place is awesome! If you are ever in the area and looking for a quick drink this is the place you have to go.

Are you a fan of fernet? Well... I definitely am and they have it chilled ready
author: Bob S.

description:
If you want to get some frat boy hipster valley girl sorority Walnut Creek bridge and tunnel plastic ass then put your best white boy Entourage act on and gather 'round with the rest of your worthless friends in the hottest budget meat market in the Divisedero Corridor!

Living within a few houses of The Page and listening to frat boy douchebags yelling "go suck some dick you fucking fag!" at 12:15am is no longer some strange occurrence, but rather the new mentality that has infected this former neighborhood bar. Gone are the days where it was a chill place with a good mixed crowd and a genuine neighborhood feel to it. 

Now you'll find the shallow plasticity of the Marina-bridge-and-tunnel crowd jockeying for some ass. Motivated by their inner need to go somewhere that's safe yet "dirty" so they can feel like they're getting their true "city" experience. It's much like the white frat boys that bump hip hop and trying to be "ghetto" because their Abercrombie lives have no culture.

The Page is dead to all of those that have taste. The current swarm of "totally like omg like he was so like looking at me and I'm gonna hella like make out with him and take in the ass if he gets me drunk enough" has destroyed this bar and the only solution to ending things is to get some real booty ass scene in there to beat the crap out of these kids and make them feel unsafe so they'll retreat back to their Disneyland neighborhoods and hometowns.
author: R B.

description: Dive bar for a younger crowd instead of an older, more alcoholic one.  They have Tecate in the can, which is pretty sweet in my book.
author: Jeff P.

description: I love this neighborhood corner bar - they have 2 pool tables and allow dogs (no food here).  The bartender is cool and the drinks are really well priced.  They have a nice selection of beers on tap as well.
author: Virginia T.

description:
The ladies and I head out for a drink at Madrone a block down from The Page. Apparently it's jazz night there on Sundays; that is what the sign said. But what they didn't say was "couples only!" We got the stare from every couple in the place, which was everyone. "The stare" cannot adequately be described without sounding like Carrie Bradshaw, so I will just say it was bad enough to turn right around and walk out knowing we were in foreign grounds and did not have the required passport. We were feeling a bit on the lonely single side but we kept looking. We persevered. 

So, we walked down to The Page. We found asylum. We were greeted with smiles, cold drinks, taxidermy (score!) and good music. You can thank yours truely for the good music and whoever accidently left two unused credits in the Juke Box.  

The beauty of any good dive bar, like here, is that you can easily keep to yourself or mingle with strangers, what ever your preference is. 

The bar stools had backs and the seats had armrests. It's the little things in life that make me happy. Nice seats, although I never had an opinion on before, are part of those little things that sometimes just stand out. One more thing that stood out was the hand dryer in the women's rest room. It was proper. Second best thing to a Dyson actually. That, I appreciated. So to who ever put that in thinking, "I hope people enjoy this and it keeps them coming back", it worked my friend, it worked, brilliantly! 

So thank you to The Page, for taking us single ladies in without judgment and reminding us that if we were not single, we may have to be listening to jazz music and the sound of bitching about trust issues or carpet samples from our boyfriends. You gotta look on the bright side!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
I started riding the 71 Noriega in the mid-eighties though it wouldn't be until the early nineties that I would discover Page street.  Having moved away from the city at the age of 20 I was never able to experiences the sinful pleasures of adulthood in my home town.  Years later I had the privilege to visit what I have decided is my favorite bar hands down.

From the funky decoration to the friendly atmosphere I can say for certain that I am as at home here as I might be riding any Noriega bus.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Great beer Selection!

Linden Street Black Lager, nice microbrew stouts and a few wild cards.

This is a dive bar that has upgraded just enough to maintain it's dive status and still appeal to folks that want more than a shot of Jack and a Bud (those that do want Jack and Bud will still fit in).

Happy hour runs until 7 and two beers (when you are buying for a friend) will cost less than $5.

Stereo played some favorites -- including Joy Division.
author: tjay f.

description:
1. ) The Page is not in lower haight!

2.) I love love love to come here on mellow (M-W) nights with friends and throw some bones or play some cribbage, or some other old person game.

3.) Staff is lovely; door guys are the nicest around.

4.) Revolving beers on tap-not always the same ole stuff; plus they always have a monthly liquor special.

5.) i would give it 5 if I even considered entering on the weekends-long and narrow setup + lotsa people = not quite as fun. Not their fault though! I love the page :)
author: Afton T.

description: Drinks are overpriced, clientele is more like what you'd expect in the Marina: obnoxious former frat guys who refer to each other as "bra" and whose humor centered around "embarrassing" drinking stories and degrading women. It was a cliche of heteronormativity.
author: Nikolas B.

description:
The Page is the Foo Fighters of bars.

Not necessarily bad, lots of redeeming qualities, and intelligently put together, but way overrated and the crowd drives me away.

Why anyone would go out of their way to go to a neighborhood bar that's not in their neighborhood is beyond me.
author: Jim S.

description:
Walked in here randomly while waiting for a pizza.  

ABITA AMBER ON TAP. Hell's yeah!  I got a great seat next to a filthy window with sunlight just making it into the joint.  Good beer-drinking music on the jukebox.  

I only went in for one happy hour beer and left. But, it was exactly what I needed.  Thanks for being there The Page.
author: Cameron M.

description:
This was stop number 3 on the the impromptu "Bar crawl of San Francisco, 2009."
It fulfilled my needs at the moment. A clean bathroom. A seat at the bar. A shot of vodka. and a clean bathroom. the first and last part was the most important ;)
author: Mia M.

description: The Page is a fun place to grab a few beers, if you're in the neighborhood. I would describe it as a quaint dive bar. The large furniture, dark wood, and built-in bookshelves give it an old-fashioned charm that I very much appreciate. Add to that a great beer selection and friendly crowd and you're left with a comfortable place to meet up with a few friends.
author: Brett B.

description: The Page is your classic dive bar. Great dark atmosphere with good tunes playing in the background. Bartenders are quick and responsive, and prices are decent. Its your quintessential neighborhood bar, awesome place
author: Phillip F.

description: The Page is perfect.  Its a great bar to meet friends at during the week.  Very local feel and it also has a dive bar feel to it.  What really makes this place is the great beer selection.  Its hard to find any bars with Pliney the Elder on Tap and that alone will always make me love The Page!
author: Ben K.

description:
For a local bar with a lot of regulars; this is a pretty decent spot. I like to go here for an early happy hour because it does get crowded quick. 

One of my favorite things about the bar is they have a monthly or weekly whiskey special. Its a great way do expand your alcoholic palate for a measly $5 bucks! 

I will say for a bar this close to Toronado I would probably expect a larger beer selection but maybe I'm being a bit picky. 

There are a few pool tables in the back room but we never really got around to enjoying them. 

Please don't bother ur pretty little head with the jukebox. Its a waste of time and money. If there are more than 10 people int he bar you are not going to be able to hear a damn thing!
author: Brittany D.

description:
My friend told me about the Page, decided to check it out. It didn't disappoint. 

I really enjoyed the old school style of the bar and it's refreshing non-hipness (we had just cruised down divis trying to escape said hipness) and the decorum is a throwback to the SF old days. 

Seems like everyone in there when we came by might have been a regular and it was packed. The bartenders were quick and attentive. Pooltable and foos in the back. I'm impressed and will be going back.
author: Jay C.

description: When I lived near the Lower Haight this was my go-to neighborhood spot and it still a favorite of mine. It can be prohibitively crowded, but even on busy nights my friends and I have been able to snag a table and post up here for a good time (added bonus when next to their excellent electronic jukebox). Ultimately, I think it's the cozy, hunting-lodge feel of this place that makes it stand out.
author: Adam S.

description:
My friends and I lovingly refer to this place as the lumberjack convention because well, everyone was wearing plaid in there (including myself...I honestly felt a little uncomfortable, i thought I was free of uniforms when I graduated high school!)  While the crowd was pretty homogenous, I still had a blast.  Lets just say playing pool while intoxicated when you suck at pool to begin with can prove incredibly embarrassing. My friend and I should never be allowed to play pool there again we were so bad.  Except, that I plan on going back and playing again, you know to get practice and whatnot...

I like this place enough and the drinks are cheap and I live close by, therefore I will be back
author: Alixandria F.

description: I'll still go back even though I think the bartenders are complete a**holes and the music is so low you can barely hear it.  It's in the hood and they have pool.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Very much down to earth bar.  We loved the games and reasonable prices.  Wasn't a fan of the 'cash only' system, but worth the atmosphere.
author: David S.

description: Definitely a pretty good dive bar. Nothing special, bartenders are nice though. Someone did steal my jacket, but that's no fault of the establishment.
author: Steve P.

description:
The Page is fun and divey on most weeknights.  On Thursdays, it sucks because it's in between divey and weekend-hipster-sceney.  On Friday nights, well, it's just sceney.  Not hipsters-only sceney, but sceney nonetheless.

What I like about this place, even on sceney nights, is that everyone seems to be afraid to crowd the lower level.  There's a pool table in the back, but if you go down the stairs, there's yet another pool table.  There's also a foosball table way by the back, and although it can often by overcrowded by annoying hipsters, it's often being used (surprisingly) by people who just want to play foosball.  That's awesome.

What isn't awesome is that the last time I was here, I was being distracted in my goalkeeper-and-back-line duties by an annoying drunk girl nicknamed Tim who wouldn't stop going on about the authenticity of her Vietnam War-era jacket.  And I wasn't distracted in that way--I was distracted because she wouldn't shut up, and my team ended up losing because of my poor goalkeeping.  I also don't like the fact that there are three goalkeepers as opposed to one, nor do I like the fact that this is a particularly dangerous foosball table because the bars extend too far and don't have rubber pads on their ends.

But it's cool hanging out down here, and the change machine works remarkably well, and if you stand in the corner you can guard your stuff effortlessly.
author: John S.

description: The Page is my favorite bar on Divisadero- reasonably priced drinks and a funky vibe. It's a good place to go with friends when you want to have a conversation without yelling. Seats are hard to come by, which is the only bummer, because there's only a few tables. I've usually been able to figure something out as far as seating, but during the week it's a good place to hang out for a low-key drink.
author: Christine T.

description:
This appears to be a nice, plain, neighborhood bar.  

On Friday the 13th my Love was in L.A., and I was looking for some decent conversation.  Kudos to Sus.annah B for keeping the DYL going in San Francisco!  At least when I am talking with Yelpers, I know the conversation will be intelligent.  

It was still daylight when I arrived at 7pm, and about a half dozen Yelpers were gathered in a window where we could watch the street and enjoy the evening sunlight.  I did indeed find the intelligent conversation I was seeking.  I also met Bill B, who keeps the DYL tradition alive in the East Bay.  

A rum and Coke cost me $4.50 + tip.  Service was about normal for 2 bartenders and a busy queue.
