Looking to the back of the room, I saw a very active pool table.  Someone also mentioned that there is a picture of a stuffed animal head back there, wondering what was the point.  I think, perhaps, it's more humane and eco-friendly?  

Many Yelpers took off for a birthday party across town, but I was content to walk back home and dream of my Lover's return.
author: David D.

description:
Place was pretty packed with what looked like college-age students. They had a great selection of beers on tap, the crowd is more laid back and casual which is nice.
Unfortunately there is very limited seating here and you might have to be standing and drinking all night. However, there are some pretty cool pool tables if you're into that, and foosball is also all the way in the back. Great little bar for chilling out - if you get a place to sit.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
This place definitely has a meeting-hall-for-mysterious-centuries-old men's-groups vibe to it.  Reminiscent of a hunting lodge, a library or an art gallery, the wood-paneled walls are adorned with deer heads, elk heads, paintings of deer heads on a wall across from an actual deer head (thanks for the alert Keith) and reproductions of fine art.  Two pool tables are available for $1 per game (though one table is poorly located in the middle of the space, causing one to nearly jab people in the eye or the nether regions with a cue stick), and foosball exists as well.

I really enjoyed the neighborhood feel of the bar - it has almost a Cheers-y thing going for it, at least during happy hour ($1 off wells and beer).  It's a great little spot to sit back and watch TV after work, maybe with the whiskey of the month for $5.50, and feel like you're at home, except even better because they probably have more booze.
author: Sus... B.

description:
Pool Table.  Plenty of seating & close by.

At times, it smells of "bar", but you come to expect that in a "bar"  ;)
author: sUper j.

description:
I'd just like to say that I have now lived in the lower Haight for almost two years and this is my favorite bar. They have a solid and unique beer selection, a good liquor selection including an ever changing whiskey of the month, pool, foosball, and a great jukebox. The ambiance is great with a friendly bar staff and a great feeling of people having a good time. I love this place. It does lose a star because it often is way too crowded. I guess people share my sentiment. 

Why do I have favor this to other lower Haight bars? Let's take a look:
1. Danny Coyle's - boring beer selection. Kinda douchie, but not, but it kinda is.
2. Mad Dog - Why is this place so empty on a friday night?
3. Toronado - as a developing beer afficionado, I have to love the ever changing unique selection of beers they have. Unfortunately they also have grumpy bartenders, the backroom with the tv smells that very much like the adjacent bathroom, and there is never a sense of people having a good time.
4. Nickie's - Too far. Fillmore St. is like an invisible fence that I can never get through.
author: Andrew M.

description: I liked The Page. We were there on a weeknight; it was nice, quiet and unpretentious despite the hipster crowd. I had a Racer 5. If it weren't 3000 miles from my home in Rhode Island I'd probably add it to my dive-bar list.
author: Amelia N.

description:
I am fond of this bar, which I'd say is an "upscale dive," for two reasons:

Exhibit A: The fact that they serve a good variety of beers, including one delightful brew known as "Moose Drool." Good to the last drop!

Exhibit B: The downstairs area that looks like someone's funky rec room circa 1980, complete with pool tables, foosball and the heads of large game animals.
author: Rachel G.

description: My neighborhood bar The Page offers everything I need in a bar: two pool tables, foosball, ample seating (gotta love the wooden tables & taxidermy vibe), and great selection of whiskey with a new type featured every month. Sure the chill weekday neighborhood vibe gives way to a slighty homogenous weekend crowd that would do better with a dash diversity. But that's not the bar's fault, is it?
author: Quentin J.

description: This small dive-y bar was on the cheap side (yeah!) but got really crowded later in the night (which is good for them & it was a Friday - just not my scene into the late night!).  Not too many hipsters (another yeah!). Beer selection was great - had a vodka tonic which was on the weak side, so when I go back, I will stick with the beer. Also had a fun game to play on the bar top - a "how are the pictures different" thing you would see in a magazine but a XXX picture.  I love the raunchiness at my dive bars!
author: stephany m.

description: One of two bars I know that I can always get Pliny.  Not being from SF, this is critically important to my experience. Honestly, couldn't care about anything else, but seems like a fun place.  It's never been too busy when I've been there, so I'd like to see the whole crowd in action...
author: Matt L.

description:
Two girls cornered me on Saturday night.  As we waited in the cramped hallway to the restroom, they began digging through their purses to find me a present.

Apparently, I had been nice to one of the girls when I asked if I could steal a chair from her table.  Then, I had been nice to the other girl when my friends and I toasted her with our kamikaze shots.

See, boys and girls?  Being nice =  free sh*t in the Ladies Room.  Err...

Emptying out their handbags, they chirped  "Take this!"  "No, take this, instead!"  After much deliberation, I selected a lip-plumping lip gloss from the JCrew worker and a compact hairbrush from the hairstylist.

I'm baffled:  Either the strong drinks helped us form a bond, or I now have herpes and lice.
author: Janney B.

description:
I was a huge fan of Chances but was excited 5 years ago when a new direction was taken. Overall I like this bar. It's local, prices are decent and service is good even when packed. The pool tables get a little cramped but it's not bad. I'd say overall it's an above average dive bar.

I Miss Chances, but support the Page...
author: Morgan A.

description:
Here is what happened last week, on a Monday night, at 11pm, which brought me to this average, dimly lit, loungy in a dated way, semi-hip neighborhood watering hole;

*ring* 
*ring*

Me - "Hello"
Ed - "What are you doing? Lets go drink!"
Me - "No. I am tired. I can't"
Ed - "WHY?" (sound of desperation in his voice)
Me - "It's Monday, plus I have an interview tomorrow so I need to be well rested"
Ed - "But, come on....."
Me - "Absolutely not, no way, no how"
Ed - "Please...we can meet at a bar halfway between us"
Me - "No, I have to sleep!"
Ed - "Rookie"
Me - "I'll be there in 15 minutes"

Rookie? What?? I showed him!!
author: Drue C.

description:
Woooaahhh Gabe gave a bar 2 stars?  Yess siirrr
Woooaahhh Gabe gave a bar in his hood' 2 stars?  Yes sirrr
Woooaahhh Gabe gave a bar that makes DJC's 2 stars? Yes sirrr

So why didn't Gabe give this bar 1 star if he doesn't like it?  Tupac Baby!  They got Tupac on the Juke Box..  Name 5 other bars in SF that play Tupac?  I know one other (Thieves Tavern).

Any place where the owner tells you to move away from the door because customers think you are the Bouncer/Doorman, is weak!  ( I got yelpers to prove it) fuck that.. put your doorman outside next time.  

Will the real Doorman please stand up?  His name is Brian.. good dood!  Nothing bad to say about him.

I've been to Page a handful of times and not once did I really enjoy myself.
*********
update 2 days later ;0)
*********
So add a star for 3 reasons... 
1) Owner was working the door and we discussed what had happened 2 days earlier... I have a lot more respect for the man today.
2) what's that bartenders name?  Rachel?  Hi Rachel
3) THEY GOT MOTHA FUCKIN PAC ON THE BOX!!!
author: Jamal G.

description:
How the hell did I get here from Jade?

Did I really go there?

Can someone tell me?


_________                                                                                ___________
|                   |                                                                                |                        |
|   JADE      |                                  ? ME ?                                  |  THE PAGE  |
|                   |                                       O                                      |                        |
|      6pm     |                                      / | \                                     |       12am      |
|.________|                                       /\                                      |__________.|
                                       still wondering 2 days later
author: Margie B.

description:
Once I had a date with the dreamiest girl here. What started late at The Page ended at her place, where we fooled around with Zoolander quietly on in the b/g (both of us had seen it, never WATCH anything when you're necking). The, um, feelings we shared that  night, well let's just say that in the light of day, the dream was dead. Today dead's about the only time I like (and LIKE's a strong word) The Page. There on a holiday weekend. When it gets "hopping". Ugh.

At its best The Page draws just enough wallet chains so that their patrons with endowments, trust funds and such, won't be a-scared. To yuppies it resembles a dive JUST enough. To scruffy wide-belters it saves them the inconvenience of hauling their slim asses down to La Mission. A real meeting of the minds when you see Yuppio And Hipsterette sharing blow in one of The Page's many dark corners.

Basically a Two Star joint. And I'll bump it One for making me laugh. There's something about standing outside ANY bar talking to Gabriel when a Carload Of Whitey starts handing him their IDs as though he's Bouncy Von Bouncerton that never fails to crack me up.

And there's no Hard Cider on tap. The Page had better amuse me again soon or I'm putting that Star in cold storage. At the very least I hope the lighting there limns me up good because I REALLY need to see Zoolander again.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I'm unsure why I've never been to The Page prior to last night.  I've passed by it enough and it's on the outskirts of my hood.  Thanks to a co-worker suggesting it for a place to meet up, I finally made it here.

Not much to say other than it's your typical dive bar.  They do have an impressive list of beers on tap and in the bottle.  My favorite being Arrogant Bastard!  It was a bit hoppy for me, but I liked the name so much I got it!

The clientele seems local and pretty low key.  It got a bit crazy for a while with only one bartender but she was working hard for the money!   They have two pool tables so if that's your thing, it's a good place to come!  I also liked the fact that there was abundant seating around at least one of the pool tables so people could watch.

I think I'll be back to this bar...it's close enough to walk and/or a short ride on the 24.  I've also made it a resolution to get to know more beers so this is a good local place to do so!
author: Melanie N.

description:
As charming as I can be, I am, fundamentally, one scary lady. AK doesn't mess around. So it would probably be really stupid of you to pack yourself and your girlfriends three-deep in the one women's stall at the Page and proceed to sniff, snort, and giggle your way through what I can only imagine is a bag full of blow, on MY time while I WAIT to pee. Over and over again throughout the night. That would not only be stupid, that would be potentially dangerous. I may start to become impatient. I may knock and passive-aggressively ask when you bitches plan on coming out. I may huff and puff and blow the door down before shooting eye-daggers at you for the rest of the night until you curl up in a little ball and cry for your mother. Or I may simply tell the bar staff what you're up to and have them escort your bleached blonde ass out.

Such was the case on a recent trip to the Page. And even with all that dim-bitchery, I had a pretty good time. The crowd is a lot lighter on the douchebag hipster NOPA (please stop calling it that! It's the WESTERN ADDITION. I KNOW. I GREW UP HERE) crowds at Fly, Madrone, and Waziema put together. And when our favorite neighborhood spot closes early, as they're known to do, I think The Page will be our new default hang out. Door man, You Rock! Bartender with the curly hair, You Rock! Bartender with the ponytail, You Rock! Guy in hooded sweatshirt with long hair undressing me with your eyes on the sidewalk, You Don't Rock! But you didn't bother me nearly as much as you would have had we been outside of Fly. 

The drinks were fairly cheap, there's a lot of space and ample seating (though it gets pretty packed), there are pool tables and a fireplace and all kinds of boys. This is the friendliest bar staff in the hood, with the exception of Bar 821, and they serve alcohol right up til 1:45 a.m. Now that's my kind of place.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I was told that my reviews are all about men and getting laid. 

Fuck yeah they are!!!  I live vicariously through my own journalistic whims and imaginary illusions. 

On that note....here goes yet ANOTHER wistfully lustful anecdote:

The Page is a bonafide sausage fest.  My party pal colleagues of the night decided to rate the bar on a scale of penises....or penii if you will (and YOU KNOW that I will).

We gave The Page a very decent three penii score.   A horde of boys (a few even being attractive) and cheap drinks. 

If I new about this place when I lived in the area a couple years ago I could've gotten laid WAY MORE often than I did.
author: Jay H.

description:
I had a short, intense affair with the Page which ended in a spectacularly bad fashion, as it set the stage for an extremely negative turn of events in my life and ever since, I just can't really come here and have any fun. The other thing is that since moving to the neighborhood, I find that this place is always really crowded and just doesn't have that low key, neighborhood bar, life is rough, let's just have a drink, appeal that I crave.  

I do however, greatly enjoy their jukebox.
author: Maria D.

description:
Foooooooooooooosball!

 I had barely played since my days in San Diego, when I lived in a house with 4 other dudes & our lives consisted of surfing/skating & weekly Foosball/Ping-Pong tournaments (yes, we even had a scoreboard). Our biggest problem was deciding on what type of beer would stay cold in the kegerator, and I was on my way to becoming a professional Foos player.

Times have changed.

I have lost my skills on the table, but with the help of The Page they will return yet again & I will be an unstoppable Foos-force. And the fact that I can rock out to their well-stocked digital jukebox will keep me in the Foos-Zone. And if there's a song they don't have, I can simply download it!

Let's not forget about their beer selection, either. It ranges from PBR to Chimay & even some obscure stuff like an Oatmeal Beer. I even decided to throw it back to my San Diego days while I was at this spot... and have an Arrogant Bastard--it's brewed down south.

The bar staff was quick & friendly, even though it was later on a Saturday evening and the crowds were high. I suggest checking this place out on a less crowded evening for a better experience.

Minus one star for charging $3 for PBR, the most ANYONE should EVER charge for PBR is 2 BUCKS. 

Foosball tournament, anybody???
author: matt m.

description:
The Page is a good place to start the night, or go early in the afternoon for a few drinks.  Later in the night the bar area gets packed, the pool tables are way too cramped, and it feels like you're just hanging out in an extra wide hallway. Sometimes the bar tenders are a little on the snobby side, but they give my girlfriend free drinks usually so I guess I can live with it. Definitely worth checking out if you've never been before.

They've got a lot of good beer consistently on draft and a foosball table so it for sure gets 4 stars from me.
author: Cameron S.

description:
Yelp review:  All High School Elite Edition:

DYL, June 27, 2009, there I was, standing at the bar getting ready to order my 4th pint . . . well I should back up.  

So a few of us went to DYGay at Martuni's ( http://www.yelp.com/biz/martunis-san-francisco#hrid:iMeBruWXW8MntLVlq6Drhw ), but it ended early since Gregor, Winnie and Adrienne G all decided to leave (was it my breath?), but at that exact moment Critical Mass hit Market Street at Valencia, rendering it nearly impossible to get a cab or even a bus up to the lower Haight, so Rachel F and I walked up to Haight and something or other and finally caught a cab, arriving just in time to see Starla and Matt crossing Divis to the liquor store across the street from the Page ("going to get some booze?" I taunted).

Rachel F and I went inside to find Stefan, Bill, Drue and Autumn.  We ordered a couple of pints on my dime (Rachel F informed me of the yelp rule that the ROTD winner buys the drinks - and boy am I glad!  Imagine my embarrassment had I not known and made her pay for her own drink!  Dodged that bullet - phew!).  We both got carded, which is always charmingly amusing given my gray hair (I do *not* look 45, Jaime!  Take that back!).  I ate a little of Autumn's bday cake (yummy, chocolate - thank you for being born, Autumn!).  Starla and Matt got back from the liquor store . . . hmm, weird.  I shot some pool with Bill and had a couple more pints.  (We went 1-1 on our first two games, each of us scratching on our ultimate 8-ball shot to lose games that we should have won). I went back to the bar to order another pint.  

Bartender: "ID?"
Me: [apparently with a load of unintended snark] "Uhm - it's all the way back down at the pool table in my jacket with the three empty pint glasses I already drained . . . do you want me to go get it?"
Bartender: [looking remarkably irritated and offended] "You could just say 'I've already been carded.'"
Me: "I've already been carded . . . I wasn't trying to be a dick, sometimes it just comes out sounding that way . . ."

Anyway - he gave me my pint, I beat Bill fair and square on the 3rd and final game, and then I went home.

As for the bar . . .
Minuses:  a bartender who is easily offended; pool table felt that feels like the carpeted floor of a porn theater (don't ask how I'd know); Starla kept sneaking up on me.

Plusses:  Great beer selection; two pool tables; I got carded twice; change machine to get quarters for the pool table; chocolate cake; it's close enough for me to walk home (yay!) . . . .

4 stars for lots of yelpers, good beer, and thinking that there might be a snowball's shot in hell that I am under 21.
author: Joe C.

description: Great people watching here.  Solid beer choices, especially Pliny the Elder.  The red chairs mentioned are full of broken dreams for sure, but strangely comfy.
author: Brian S.

description: Decent beer selection, fair prices.  The bar staff has always been fairly friendly and quick with service when I've visited.  There is more seating than it would seem from the outside -- including a back room with pool table and more chairs/tables.  I always have a great time here but enjoy it best early in the evening or late at night (it makes a great stop for a last drink after shows at the Independent).
author: Heidi M.

description:
I love dive bars. Always have, probably always will and so when I am in other parts of our fine world and exploring civilizations outside of Hell-A, I definitely like to get at least a few dives in before I consider it a successful trip. With that said, I found a cool one to add to the list. 

Apparently this place used to be a hardcore lesbian bar and was a rumored sh*thole, but now it seems as though it has been cleaned up a bit and is nicer than it was in prior years. I don't even wanna imagine how bad it was then, because it still definitely falls into the super dive category.

As for the vibe, it was a Tuesday night when we hung out here so it wasn't the hipster clusterf*ck I seem to be reading about in other reviews. True, there were hipsters, many of whom were wearing awesome outfits and one super sassy vixen hooked me up with a great vintage dress tip, but for the most part it was just full of seemingly down to earth folks enjoying some early week cocktails.

I would hit this place if I just wanted to grab a drink or 4 with some friends or wanted to shoot some stick, as they have a few pool tables in the back.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I owe this place a review, even though I don't have any strong feelings for this place one way or the other.

This bar has all the fixings of a decent watering hole.  It features a rustic decor, quality bar lighting, and gaming tables.  They feature a good selection of alcohol served up by an attentive bar staff.

Here's the short and skinny: Seems like a good neighborhood bar.  I didn't feel that this place was anything so special that I would trek half way across the city on a regular basis.
author: Christopher K.

description: Best mid-week bar in the city. Devoted locals with a quality selection of drinks and not to mention foosball.
author: John W.

description:
The Page reminds me of Sinbad's. 

Sinbad's is this place on the east end of the Detroit River. In the GHETTO. Seriously, the ghetto. Not the Tenderloin.

So, so, super-duper cool. Been there since the 40s. Seafood joint and bar with its own marina, and people pull up to it on their boats. They have great fried catfish... Mmm. And a delicious soul food Sunday brunch... Oh damn! I miss that brunch. And upstairs in the summer, the patio is open, and the menu up there is ALL catfish. Catfish everything. Fried catfish and catfish salad and catfish po' boys...

Inside, it's dark: all the time. Even when they pull up the shades on the big windows that overlook the little marina, it's still dark. The interior walls are just DARK. Lots of paneling, and wood finishes... And they have a great big painting near the bar of an old galleon on fire, and I remember when my dad used to take me there as a kid, just staring at that painting... At the brilliant red of the flames eating the boat alive... Thinking it was the brightest thing in the whole damn place.

Keeping with the nautical theme, there are ships' portholes in the doors to the restrooms. The chairs and barstools are leather upholstery with brass buttons: very captain-like. And on the placemats, there's a mermaid throwing a net over the word "Sinbad's," spelled out in ship's line. And she's bare-chested (though she doesn't have any nipples, of COURSE). I remember always being embarrassed by her boobies as a kid, and making sure to set my water glass right on top of them...

At night the place gets rowdy with the sun-tanned boater crowd. All the people moored down in the marina come up to get their schwerve on -- outside on the patio if the weather's nice. I'd feel bad for the neighbors, but hey -- this is Detroit. All the houses on the street that dead ends at Sinbad's are abandoned.

So now I've painted a completely incorrect picture of the Page for you.

It is NOT in the ghetto.

It does NOT serve seafood, or soul food.

It does NOT have a nautical theme.

It does NOT have a marina, nor is it anywhere near the water.

However...

It DOES have those same leather-upholstered chairs and barstools, and it IS dark, and it has more or less the same vibe... In that same cozy, cabin-like way. 

It DOES have lots of people getting their schwerve on. They likely came from the Panhandle or Lower Haight, and not off their boats. And they're definitely not sun-tanned, because this is San Francisco. But schwerve is schwerve.

And, with enough schewervin', it probably COULD have some boobies, too. Maybe not of the mermaid variety, but I think boobies are boobies, right?
author: Lisa T.

description:
Friendly people, good drinks, clean bathroom.

That's really all I need in a bar and The Page has all 3. Minus 1 star for being cash only, but I'd still go back.
author: Sarah P.

description: Not my favorite bar but serviceable if you are in the area. It's downright impossible to play pool here because of the placement of the tables and crowded bar. Drinks are ok but not memorable.
author: Michael C.

description:
"If the doors of perception were cleaned, we would see infinity" -William Blake(quoted by Huxley at the introduction of The doors of perception).

My experience at Page last night was similar to the time I took some strong shrooms in Burning Man the afternoon before the Burn. Initially, it was nothing spectacular but suddenly the Playa turns into a gigantic ice skating ring. After some moments(minutes/hours?) of wonder, I close my eyes and I see a huge volcano erupting lavas in my mind's eye. Both the outer and the inner experience of fantasy are so strong that I am struggling between keeping my eyes open or closed.

I reached Page last night already very drunk from the combination of free and Happy hour priced booze plied on me by the loving bartenders of Jade. I sit at the Bar in Page and down a few Coronas in rapid succession. I wonder around and talk to yelpers as well as random people playing pool, fuzball or footsie.

Suddenly, I come back to the Bar and dose off. I see volcanoes erupting lavas in my mind. I open my eyes and see the color red everywhere. From deer heads frozen in eternity on the red walls to the  Eternal Godhead erupting redness in my mind, I am awash in an ocean of red and my inner and outer experience becomes One.

Today I am facing the aftermath of volcanoes erupting in my head last night. However, I will still give a good rating to this Bar as it is a friendly, high end dive/local Bar and I can see that once people(esp. from the broader neighborhood) gets a feeling of familiarity and comfort(like I have at Jade) they come back again and again to Page.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
oh...the page. How I love you...let me count the ways:

1. Drinks are strong and almost always available when I need them
2. People flock here from near and far, leading to a usual run-in with old random characters from my past.
3. If you like scotch--and I don't mean tape--they have a good selection
4. There a pool table...that's not always bogarted by dark and nasty types so you can go here on off nights and still enjoy yourself

Overall, this is a key component of my social life in San Francisco. I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Jane K.

description:
Oh yeah, DYL.  Gotta love it.

By the time my cousin and I got there most of the yelpers had already cycled through.  Got to meet a few cool people and the bartenders were nice and attentive.

It's an attractive albeit cramped space, especially later in the evening when you are trying to play pool.  If you don't mind a pool cue being shoved in to parts of your lower anatomy it's not so bad I suppose.  

This isn't as laid back of a spot as I usually enjoy (Kennedy's, Zeitgeist, etc) but as far as bars go I can see myself coming here again.

Two pool tables and a foozeball table.  A dozen or more beers on tap and a full bar.  Larger than average collection of scotch.
author: Theron L.

description: Another vote for this being a pretty good neighborhood bar in a good location.  The interior is nothing too special.  Definitely earns an additional star for having *both* a foosball table and a pool table.  The exterior has that great 50's San Francisco bar feel with the old neon and wall signage, flat stone wainscotting and palm trees.
author: Rick H.

description:
The back room with the pool table is a great place to have a surprise birthday party. But, you will still have to order all your drinks at the bar as apparently, there is no table service. 

The ambiance is sort of stuffy study, meaning don't bring your hardcore vegetarian or vegan friends here. There are multiple species represented only by their heads on various walls. 

Two pool tables, and a genial crowd, yes crowd, for a Monday night. The bartenders were cute and helpful. Maybe that's why they get a crowd, eh? I wouldn't call this a destination but I would feel comfortable dropping in if I was walking by.

Parking can be tricky.
author: Miel H.

description:
The Page is a relaxed neighborhood bar situated right where the Castro, Lower Haight, and the Western Addition all come together. Yelp says that it belongs to Lower Haight, but far as I'm concerned it's a Western Addition bar. LH already has tons of bars and we need more; The Page is ours. And when I say 'relaxed' I mean that it's relaxed as a bar can be on a friday night when it's full of yelpers and a wedding party.

The decor is somewhere between small town watering hole and hunting lodge. There's pool and foosball. Neither the brick nor the deer heads are real.

It can be hard to get the attention of the bartenders when it's busy, but when you do it's worth it.

They have Shiner Bock on tap, people.
THEY HAVE SHINER BOCK ON TAP.

The 7 and the 24 run right by this place and there are tons of cabs on Divisadero at night. But there's another way to get here, evidently:

1. Go to Jade and have a bunch of cocktails.
2. Close your eyes. You'll begin to slip into a trance.
3. When you regain conciousness, open your eyes and you're sitting at the bar at The Page.

I can't explain the science behind it, but several people have independently verified that it works.
author: matthew r.

description:
"Lets go to the page"...seems to be the failsafe.  After a house party, after another bar, after a concert, pretty much after anything, or just for drinks mid week.  
We have our town meetings here.  When our friends need a mid week cocktail, we head here.  The bouncers know our faces, the bartenders pretty much know our drinks, and at one point in my history at the Page, a certain few friends of mine could always be spotted at the foos ball table.  I like this bar.  Its comfortable, they helped me take over the downstairs area for my 29th birthday, providing me with forks and plates for cake my friends baked.  
Its walking distance to my home.  sometimes it feels like home.

minus the one star for the overpriced fernet shots.
author: Lauren F.

description: The Page is a comfortable bar with a bit of fun and entertainment... I love when I pop in and there is live music. Even when it's not live, they play great songs. They supply a good selection of whiskey -which is my drink and so that make me very very happy. When me and my room mate stop in, we like to play pool and foosball with random people from the neighborhood. There's also a really cute guy behind the bar named Ryan -another perk to the place. : )
author: Amaline B.

description: Not sure why this place is so popular. It's a pretty crappy bar with pretty crappy drinks and pretty crappy service. It's always packed and loud and just not where I want to go to drink. There are way too many better places around to bother with this place just because it's become trendy.
author: Alex R.

description:
The Page was neither here nor there...  The ambiance would have been far more charming if it hadn't been packed with people... we did find a table rather easily... But, I ask why is it when I am in a narrow bar sitting at a table, inevitably men choose to stand with their asses in my face?

I suppose it's better than the alternative.

The drinks were fine... mine had far too much vodka, my companion's had far too little gin.

I liked the dark reddish interior of The Page... it felt very... very from another time.

I don't remember much else about this bar as I was engrossed in conversation, which is always a good sign.

Three stars - unremarkable bar, only made stellar by the company who I choose to spend my time there with.
author: Kate R.

description:
Like dive bars, but hate bacteria? Love fooseball,  but hate douchebags?
The Page is your new jam, hombre. The Page has the esthetic of a rustic hunting lodge / rompus room. The front tables are a great place to take down one of the many beers on tap or the reasonably priced c-tails while listening to some hot licks from the jukebox. 
The front room empties into the a open downstairs area. 
I may be the only one, but I for one love the stairs that lead to nowwhere on the left side of the lower bar area.
Post up on these stairs w/ a peer and shoot the breeze and you will swear you were stoopin it in Crooklyn on a breezy Autumn day.
author: Gabe b.

description: I'm a huge fan of The Page when this place is packed with people.  It's the people that make this such a fun place.  Especially on those $3 Wednesdays.
author: Mike V.

description:
God, remember when this bar was called Chances?
Chances are you'd find someone to go home with at the end of the night.

I love the Page, the drinks are cheap, the jukebox is beefy and there's a pool table in the back. It's laid back, has enough charm to not scare away the locals but not gaudy enough to catch a tourist's eye. 

It's a chill local hang, it's got potential for good people watching and I find myself goin there more and more.
author: Jessica P.

description:
This place sucks.  No, Lindsay, I don't want to play Foosball, and FUCK the internet jukebox.  If you can't pick out a group of CDs that you want played in your bar, then you don't even fucking deserve a jukebox.

Oh, and your bartenders are totally never nice to me.  And I haven't done anything to deserve that kind of treatment.  

AND there are never any cute boys here because, well, why would there be?  And the bathrooms are stupid and awkward.  And fuck you all.  

I think I have made my point.
author: Coco D.

description: Definitely a favorite in the hood although it can get very cramped very quickly in here. I have been a few times but most notably I stopped by on a Sunday afternoon to find it 1) not crowded at all and 2) awesome happy hour specials. The bartender was really nice and my BF and I sat for a few hours chatting and drinking. Definitely enjoyable!
author: Alissa C.

description:
The Page is that place on the corner that is filled with all the locals! This is the neighborhood bar you'd read about in a Bukowski book, or the type of place where you leave all the "bar scene" pretensions behind and just have a beer and a shot. Excellent local secret...or it was, the secret has gotten out (blast!) 

They have a pool table, endless jukebox, gamebox, super bartenders, foozball and a crowd that is relaxed and friendly! Sure it's dark, smells a little bit and has mounted deer heads in back...it is awesome and by no means, lacking in character. 

Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights this place is *PACKED* with people. Get their early and prepared to be bumped into and/or spilled on. Part of me is happy because this spot definitely deserves all the success in the world, but the content of folks on the weekend honestly makes me want to leave...or scream out "I WAS HERE FIRST!!!!"
author: Beth M.

description:
Nice dive bar with a nice booze selection (they even had Titos!).  I arrived fairly early in the evening and watched the bar fill up with amazingly normal people (which is saying a lot for SF).  No marina choads, no punks, hippies, or drag queens -- just people like you and me.  Well...maybe not you.  

The booze was fairly priced, and the jukebox actually had most of my favorite bands on there (bless you, internet jukebox).  This is a mixed blessing however...while you can put on that obscure song you like, some jackhole can also put on really shitty music that'll make you want to leave.
author: Eugene F.

description:
I would love to come back to this bar when I am not already completely shit faced. 

Pool, fooz-ball, music, cool peeps, and its surprisingly large! The back area opens up to an area with the pool table & fooz-ball. A great mix of people. Bring I.D.,  I actually had my I.D. checked when I came in, which has never happened to me! 

Plus, there is a FANTASTIC pizza place down the street! YUM!

I will definitely be back!
author: Jessica R.

description: I've been here slammed on a half a bottle of tequila, and stone sober, always with a large group of friends. Arrogant Bastard on tap? Meet you there!
author: Alita M.

description:
My neighborhood bar.  Nice happy hour specials...but you won't catch me here on weekends.  FAR too crowded.  Where did all these poeple come from!?  Must be because they don't charge a cover like Madrones down the street.

 So it is my week night pool hall equipped with erotic photo hunt, a loud jukebox and a mounted deer head.  Grandpa would be proud.
author: Julie C.

description:
$3 beers.  Do I really need to write any more?  I was there by myself and not much in the mood to socialize so I was thrilled with the chill atmosphere and cheap good beer.  I heard some good music come out of the juke box and got a great $12 buzz.  

If I am ever with a friend and we just need a chill place to go have a drink and shoot the shit this will be on the list of options.
author: Ian M.

description:
I appreciate that the Page is a dive; one can only tolerate so much sojo-bar bullshit. While you might go to "Bar 415" for a sake cocktail and to show off your new ironic hat, you go to the Page to get drunk. 

The thing is, drunk people are assholes. It follows that this place is  usually full of assholes. It might be better if the bar staff were nice, but that hasn't been my experience, esp. with the female bartenders. At best, they do this good-bartender-bad-bartender shtick that gets old fast. This is the kind of place where tipping isn't correlative to the service.
author: Jabe N.

description: When I lived a few blocks from The Page I found it hard to let myself be charmed by the place (even despite the ridiculously off-kilter boy to girl ratio.) Perhaps absence makes the heart grow fonder, though. Now I'm inclined to think that despite the dingy carpeting and strange lighting, The Page is a perfect spot for one's last drink of the evening, preferably a shot of Fernet with a ginger back.
author: Miriam W.

description:
THE HOME OF THE TOWN MEETING.

Alas, like any great place where family gather to drink themselves silly, it's got flaws. Just like the rest of us. Hey, are we not human? Or....a bar? Drinks are a bit overpriced (okay, a LOT in cases), but it's cozy & the bartenders are lovable, no-nonsense types, & it's just HOME. In a bar.

Always packed with locals from the Western Addition/NOPA/Haight areas, ignore the "sausage-fest" complaints. My crew rolls with a slew of cute girls. If you were there & it was full of dudes, well, wrong night I guess.

In conclusion, I LOVE THE PAGE.
author: Pete J.

description:
I'm not sure if it's the fake wallpaper bookcases in the back room, or the random moose heads hanging from the walls, or the foosball thats slightly sticky with beer residue, but this place feeds my dive-loving soul in a way that few bars can. We came with a random motley crew, made new friends, I learned some (much needed) new tricks at the pool table, and we stayed far past the intended departure point. Plus, they have Photo Hunt! And if you play the sexy-dude versions, you're almost guaranteed to make it into the hall of fame because NO ONE likes the dude games. Talk about a cheap boost for your ego!

This would be 5 stars except that the service was slow on a crowded night, and there was no music playing unless you put moolah into the jukebox.  I will be back.
author: Chelsea R.

description:
After a night of art at White Walls and cocktails at Bourbon & Branch a friend invited me to The Page bar. I didn't know what to expect and actually don't ever really set expectations so I don't know why I said that. I was so excited when I walked in to see a cute bar, not too packed (and the crowd that was there was lovely), plenty of seating, two pool table in a quaint room in the back set down about 4 steps. There are corners you can sit in if you want privacy and there are large table areas if you have a small group. The staff was on the ball as well as friendly, meaning I got my drink within 3 minutes of entering the bar and served with a smile. I do agree, if you're a single girl, the guys are aplenty and very social. 

It's rare to go to a bar and feel like it has it all, and this is how I felt about the Page. I would definitely recommend it if you haven't been.
author: Patience E.

description:
Aside from Golden Gate Park, this is one of the places I miss most about living in SF. We used to live north of the Panhandle and the Page was our favorite local. It's one of those places you can always count on to be fun when you can't decide what to do or where to go. The Page, of course!

My husband and I inevitably ended up meeting new people and having funny conversations with random strangers here, because it's just that kind of place. The bartenders were super nice and the "makeout room," you know that little tiny room with two stools right by the first pool table? It's awesome! I love love love this bar!
author: kelly m.

description:
Took me a while to make it by, but I really like this bar.  I remember going to Chances a few years back and not thinking much of it, and I'm not sure what is really different now, but it's a great neighborhood spot.  I stopped by recently on a Wednesday and it was surprisingly happening for a mid-week night.

I'd so much rather be here than some wannabe LA style bar in the Tendernob with 10 dollar drinks and bottle service.
author: George C.

description:
I came here after work one day to meet a friend and during the half hour I was there waiting I was the only female and the only one under 30 besides the bartender, which made me feel a bit self-conscious, so I buried my head in a copy of The Onion. 1 star.

But then a strange man in a pinstripe bought me a drink. I was momentarily convinced that he might be Willie Brown, being that I'd never actually seen a picture of Willie Brown, and was basing this solely on reputation. Either way, free drink. 5 stars.

It was a decent enough place to have a beer and a conversation, but we rather quickly moved on. Before leaving I ended up spending 5 minutes wandering around trying to find the women's restroom. A man yelled at me for trying to use the men's room. I felt like a dumbass again. 3 stars.
author: Sharon T.

description:
The reason there are so many guys around is that this is the perfect place to just go with a buddy and chat and kind of half watch TV, listen to music, etc. I've also seen a lot of groups of women hanging out, too, so maybe when I go on the weekdays it's just a hang with friends kind of place? Weekends are a lot better than other Lower Haight bars, because it's a little off the beaten path, but, it's still sometimes crazy crowded. 

Am I the only one who didn't like the former owners when this place was Chances? One brother was nice, the other guy would get drunk and crazy (or, I sure hope he was drunk because he was definitely crazy, seemingly looking for a fight in his own bar and generally starting a ruckus on a few occasions that I saw). All I know is that I like the much more peaceful vibe of the place now. 

My only small criticism is that your drinking experience varies wildly based on who's serving you. The dude who owns it is super-cool and really knows his booze, there's a girl there who has recently been wearing an "i heart beer" hat who is great as well, but some of the other bartender women I've had the last few months did not seem to familiar with their alcohol selection--I had to point out to them where bottles of not-too-rare stuff was!
author: Josh K.

description: tends to be a bit crowded, and can be hard to order.  I dig the decor though
author: Michael E.

description:
Looking for a good bar with a pool table where you're not likely to get into a fight over it?

Welcome to the Page.

Lots of tap beers. Good selection of whiskeys. Quiet Sunday through Monday so you can show up with a decent sized group and have some space. Great jukebox that no one ever seems to hog up.

The bathrooms aren't the taj mahal but they get the job done.

.....and they have foosball which used to be my favorite pasttime.....and yes it's a tornado which makes all the difference...

Great thursday through Saturday if your looking for that full bar action...


In my opinion it's great anytime
author: Michael O.

description:
WOO HOO for bars that are crowded and you can get drunk in.

-----------------------------------------------------------
*Um. I think I wrote this after I got back from this place at 2am. Not quite the kind of review you want to look for... especially since it's a bit facetious. 

So I will say, now that I am clear and sober, that this place was really crowded, dark, old, a little smelly... I'm not sure I'd go there again unless I had a good reason to. I actually got a little claustraphobic it was so damn crowded. 

It seems like a cool bar to be in if you don't care about what the people you're with are saying since it's so loud, or you don't care that you can't find a place to sit... Because you really can't talk or hear or sit anywhere in this place. 

But hey, you can always just get drunk!
author: Chantal H.

description:
I have only been here 3x (and have lived a block away for 6 years),Solid low-key vibe. Utterly non-hip, nonjudgmental and on all the nights I was there the crowd was pleasantly diverse. 
If you end up liking it too, buy me a drink.
author: tara s.

description:
Where's my oxygen tank and goggles?  The diviest place within walking distance of my place, it's not really Western Addition, but I've strolled home scarily drunk from this spot before.  Also, while 821 is nice for stopping in to have a beer or two and chill, this is where you go to get hopelessly destroyed and experience the pains of delirium tremors the next day.  Did I say that out loud?  Oops.

The douchebaggery that forces me to walk on certain sides of Divis as I head home is fortunately missing from The Page.  It's got all of the kitsch of a velvet Elvis, and if you have a problem with that, there's a soju-tini and corny assholes waiting for you a few blocks north.

The Page is my favorite bar in SF that I don't have to cab it to, bar none.
author: Sterling M.

description:
NOT welcoming of outsiders.

I used to really enjoy the Page... it was easy going and a good place for a couple of beers and some pool. I am not sure what changed with this place recently, but it doesn't  stack up to the usual standard of welcoming that great cities in the US have shown me in the last few years. 

A bar that does not let people from outside the US buy a beer without first bringing your passport (despite being a local) is not one that I would call welcoming. Frown on you Page. 

Good thing there are plenty of places in the area that appreciate us out of towners.
author: Michael B.

description:
Love this place.

Live a block away, and it's always a good atmosphere! I would have given it a five if I could use my credit card over there...
author: Ryon H.

description:
I love this bar... 
very old tavern feel to it, you walk in and feel like you took a step back.. the bartenders are super friendly.. i went on a weekday so i didnt have to deal with the crowds everyone else is complaining about. 
The jukebox is filled with random music so i guess something for everyone.
Drinks werent not anything too pricey, typical i guess. . . 
they have two pool tables, and a foosball (sp?) table in the lower section. 
its a nice neighborhood bar, ill be sure to stop in again if i am around there.
author: jamie z.

description:
The page is a pretty cool dive bar.  It's got foose (awesome) and two pool tables, which is a good reason to go.

It's a little gloomy and has (I think) ugly red carpeting which is something I insist on for dive bars.

The Page is all about the back room.  That's where the fooseball table is and the pool table with room to make a shot.  There's also a quarter machine, which is good, 'cause pool game cost you something absurd, like a buck.  The room is down some steps so it's all private feeling with a few tables.  An awesome place to get to early and dominate with your friends.   
However, if you're down there and your not dominating it, some other dumbasses are going to show up and then you'll be thinking "Mrreh?  Who the F are these douche bags?  I don't drink in the back room so I can be next to these fools.  I'm out."  Well, that's if you're me.  I don't like to meet people when I'm playing pool.  

Bring your friends.  Dominate back room.  repel back room creeping people.
author: Lee P.

description:
I remember when this was chances. 
My western addition friends like to come here but I favor the 821 place more. The bartenders can be a mixed bag. Good juke. They make a strong  drink. I was not happy that  my IPOD was  stolen out of my jacket here.
author: Jennifer S.

description: At first I thought that this bar was aight, it was around the corner from my friend's place and we'd go there sometimes on Friday nights.  After a few evenings here, I realized The Page is crawling with sleazy guys in their late thirties, early forties.  My friend met a guy here that was a musician who lived nearby and who turned out to be a total creeper.  If you don't care about the clientele, the drinks are alright and the male bartender is nice, but otherwise, go elsewhere!
author: Julia D.

description:
I've been here just a few times and like the dark, neighborhood, dive bar feel. However, I had something happen there that has never happened to me at a bar before. 
I ordered a draft beer and it was really sour. I had my friend taste it too, and he agreed it was way "off". So, he went to the bar to get me a new beer and they refused. Said they'd have to ask the owner/boss to get approval and he wasn't around! Now mind you, it wasn't like I drank the whole thing and then asked for a new one. The pint glass was down like maybe half an inch or so. 
Frankly, I couldn't believe it. It's not uncommon for tap beer to get sour and I've never been refused a new one before. Obviously I would never order a beer on tap there ever again. 
So 1 star for crappy service.
author: Margo G.

description:
It's dark, red, divey, yet lively. It's probably my favorite bar. Why: the location, the balance between dive and cozy, the beer selection. Oh, and 2 pool tables and the Foosball.

Also consider Waziema a couple blocks away (no pool tables\foos there though).
author: Julien R.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night for a birthday party and was pleased to find it hopping, but not too crowded.  Bar service was prompt and drinks were strong!

I loved the cabin decor and the laid-back vibe, but I don't ever see The Page becoming a destination bar for me.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Always good for a shit-show.  Usually me as a witness.  I've left  this fine establishment many a night drunk off  my ass.  The people seem friendly but maybe that's because I'm a fun-lovin drunk.  Who cares?  This is one of my favorite bars although the cute girls behind the bar could be happier.  
Now if only the Fulton Street Bar would come back from the dead.
author: J P.

description:
There's probably not much I can say about this place that hasn't already been said by other yelpers, but I'll throw in my two cents.

Its a classic, chill neighborhood bar. The kind of place you'd go if want to sit down, talk, and never have to wait in line for a drink. There's a full bar (great beers, including Chimay, a personal fav), pool table, and rumor has it they even have a foosball table. I was having such a good time hanging out I didnt have a chance to partake in the bar games, but no worries, it won't be long before I'm back at one of my new favorite watering holes...
author: Eran C.

description:
And on the 7th day, God created The Page.

This doesn't feel like a bar so much as the Billelo's basement circa 1978.  We'd could get some hooch from Frankie and Mikey's dad's supply and spend a whirlwind of a good time mixing it up with the locals or going head to head foosing.

When you learn about this place and you're not from the neighborhood, feel lucky, people might finally start calling you a "Local".
author: M S.

description:
I remember several years ago exploring the Castro with one of my first boyfriends... then we wandered over the hill and saw a place called "Chances." After taking our chances and checking it out, we knew we weren't in the Castro anymore, but it didn't matter because it was a friendly place.

Now that place in the Page and I still have fond memories of that night of exploration. I see it all the time since I live in the neighborhood and it's one of my favotie bars.

It gets very crowded, though, bummer.  OH and they took away erotic photo hunt!  NOOOOOOOOO that was soooooooo fun.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Ladies and Gentlemen, I am issuing a moratorium on usage of the word "dive" as an adjective that expressly modifies the word "bar".  Henceforth, you may NOT utilize the word "dive" to describe a bar unless it meets ALL of the following criteria:

1. Cash only
2. Lots of beer on tap
3. Contains pool tables
4. Bears a jukebox of any sort
5. Cheap drinks
6. TV tuned to ESPN or another sporting event
7. Blue collar clientele

Your pampered, monied, gentrified ass really has NO IDEA how to define "dive bar".  That trendy Mission joint in da hood is simply NOT a dive bar just because it's a little gritty and has a few floor stains.  Please leave the nomenclature to those who have extensive experience with such things.

That having been said, The Page is as close to a dive bar as the undiscerning socialite can approximate (minus the blue collar clientele).  It's populated by a randomly generated series of Marina assholes who undergo a serious case of cognitive dissonance: the desperate desire to be "seen at the scene" coupled with an over-inflated sense of chic and elegance.  Yet, somehow it still manages to retain its "old world" charm, those bygone days manifested by the proletariat partaking of the sweet elixir known as beer after performing some activity resulting in sweaty bodies and callused hands.

I like this place.  The drinks are cheap, the music is generated by the digital jukebox near the entrance (CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE, BITCH), and pool/foosball tables abound should you feel the need to demonstrate your drunken ineptitude.  There are a few real people here genuinely interested in conversing instead of touting their own non-achievements.  The ambiance is festive, though this is entirely fostered by the people.  The decor is typical of the "dive bar" and in no way remarkable.  But that's the way it should be.

I will return to The Page, as if it were an actual page in a novel that contained my favorite passage, some age old bit of wisdom passed down by the authors of yore.  I encourage you to read the same book.

Lan' sakes alive!  I am drunk.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
The Page is like that restaurant you go to when you're tired of eating at your usual list of places and are feeling ambitious.

It's a decent destination if you tired of skulking around the Lower Haight bars.  I like the positioning on the corners of the relatively dark and residential Page and the much busier Divisadero.

This place is a great location if you want to have some different beers.  They have Brother Thelonious (quite good) as well as Baltika (strong Russian ale).  Other than that the selection is good with a number of Bear Republic and Stone brews on tap.  They also have Hoegaarden and Trumer Pils.  The drinks were pretty stiff and with everything ringing up at about $4.50, I can see myself making my way back at some point.

What I was least crazy about (and ultimately the reason we left) was the layout of the place.  It's kind of like the walls are lined with tables, so on a Saturday when they are all full, you kind of really have no where to stand.  You can go down to the little pool room area, but then you're constantly shifting so the bastards playing pool can make their shots.  You can stay up in the bar area but then eventually someone is going to want to get by you.  It felt like our group turned into this gelatinous blob, shifting around the club in an attempt to find a place to settle down, but it just wasn't happening.  Ultimately the Page's charm wore off for me.

Props on being one of the few bars genius enough to put a change machine next to your quarter operated (pool, foosball) games, it saves you from feeling like an idiot when after much effort, the bartender comes over to you and all you order is... $2 in quarters.
author: Steven R.

description: I like this place. It is exactly what it presents itself as, a local corner bar serving beer and mixed drinks. No food. The beer selection is pretty good and it rotates depending on the season. A great place to grab a drinks with friends after dinner or before heading out.
author: Shanna T.

description:
You've gotta love this bar in theory - it's designed right, the space works, it's got good drinks, specials on the chalkboard, and the bartenders are pros.  The clientele sucks!  Not only are there insane quantities of bros, but some of them kinda scare me.  One time this dude tried to intimidate me into playing pool with him because I moved his ball after his game was over.  But bros aside, there's also weird alone 40-year-old dudes weirding everybody out, crazy lady hogging the Megatouch, and yeah, the worst possible people to ever man a jukebox, combined with the gut-wrenching freedom that internet jukeboxes afford.  311, once.  AND (I'm almost done) why is this bar always so full?  Do these people not have a couple other bars in their rotation?

Anyway, point is, it's not the Page's fault the Page sucks.  I love the Page.  Oh well.
author: Nick P.

description: The Page is a great neighborhood bar.  The bartenders are very friendly, and the beers are extremely cheap.  Plus, they have a huge selection of beers on tap.  It can get crowded on the weekends, but not too bad. They also have a jukebox and a pool table downstairs.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is a near perfect bar. Let me go down the checklist:
1 - jukebox with a variety of beats, rock and bullshit --- check
2 - a hot female bartender (JK...mmm) --- check
3 - stiff drinks --- check
4 - bar games --- check
5 - near my hood --- check
6 - feels like a dive, smells like a dive, looks like a dive - it is a dive --- check

UPDATE!!!!!!!!
Beware. If the Page looks crowded, it may be good to avoid going inside. I thought I was in the marina. Douche bags were everywhere. Maybe someone cool was slumming for their birthday. I went with two female friends. Douche after douche kept getting shot down. Calm down boys... damn. Still a near perfect bar when it is not filled to capacity.

Awesome daytime bar on the weekends.
author: Jason S.

description: The bar is pretty standard dive.  The Drinks are OK and tend to get you drunk.  But there have been more then one occasion where the scene was pretty douchey.  I would recommend to skip this one.
author: Eric B.

description:
What a funky bar.  Most of the walls are red, many of the lights are red (except for a few blue ones in back), so the overall ambiance is Red.  There are various and sundry animal heads protruding from the walls, what appears to be a whole bobcat above a door in back, and some paintings that all combine to evoke a French hunting manor feel.  Like I said, funky.
There are 2 pool tables, both in pretty good shape, and a foosball table (and a change machine).  Nice!

There's also a vast selection of whiskey, much bigger than you at first suspect, because it turns out there's a hidden cabinet on the lower left side of the bar that's stocked about 4 or 5 bottles deep with the stuff.  For those who don't like the hard likker, The Page is packing some 16 different taps or so, including a number of Belgian & German selections, as well as a couple of ciders and a bunch of local brews.  Beer prices are pretty average.  Tenders are friendly & cool folks.

Ambiance on an off night is laid back & relaxed.  It's clearly a locals' joint.  But I hear it gets pretty crazy on the weekends.

And know in advance it's cash only.
author: Don H.

description: The only place I've found in the entire city to have Magic Hat #9. Hallelujah. That is all.
author: Karena Q.

description:
I ended up here for some drinks before a game of capture the flag.  Due to where my friends live and where my office is I don't get to bars are neither in the marina or downtown so it was a nice change of pace to end up somewhere else in the city.

So the atmosphere here is relaxed and there's a pool table (or two?) in back.  The music isn't too loud and the bartender when I was there was efficient about getting drink out.  Made for a good place to have some drinks and actually talk to people instead of shouting over music.
author: Jared W.

description:
So, it's narrow, and cramped, and dimly lit, and it's not a pickup spot, but damn if I love it here.

To get things straight, The Page isn't a destination. The Page is the place you go to when you live in the neighborhood and you're looking to get bombed. It's got the kind of atmosphere that begs for an old alcoholic sitting at one end of the bar, talking to no one in particular about what it was like in 'Nam.

I'm taking one star off because I'm bitter that they're right down the block and not open at 6am for those nights when nobody's sleeping until the world runs out of beer. Bastards.
author: Nick S.

description:
Although there are several bars between me and The Page, I'm always willing to walk the extra blocks.  I prefer to go to this bar for many different reasons. 

Beer selection- the have a ton of different and varietal beers and more importantly always seem to have a few new beers to try that they don't always have around.  

The crowd-  everybody in here is always nice and simple.  People aren't too hippy, yuppie, or thuged out - they are just normal people wanting to go to a nice bar and get a drink. 

They have two nice pool tables and a foosball table - although I wish they would put a bit of money into making their foosball table nicer.  We end up going to Place Pigalle or The Rocket Room to place foos, even though we would prefer to to the page.  Just $50 towards improvements would make up for itself in drink sales in no-time!!

One of the few bars I give 5 stars!!
author: Josh M.

description:
Synopsis:  You had me at foosball.

It has some good tunes, some pool tables, relatively cheap drinks, a relaxed atmosphere.  The crowd on Friday seemed amenable if a little bit into wearing shiny button-down shirts and having exquisitely coiffed hair.  Still, they have a foosball table.  I don't think anyone can have a bad time playing foosball and you add some cheap beers on top of it - it's a three starrer.  

Unlike some of the other reviews, I didn't see the angry frat boy meat market side of things, but then again - I was pretty focused on that foosball.
author: Dave E.

description:
One star because they serve drinks, another one because they play music.  Yup.  Two stars for actually being a bar.  

They serve one of the worst martinis in town; the bar is too narrow and has a pool table as inconveniently located as possible, between the main bar area, the bathrooms, and downstairs.  The worst part, though, is that everyone else likes it and drags you there, and it takes too long to get drinks to numb the pain of being in one of the most overrated establishments in San Francisco.
author: Phil K.

description:
I really like this place. It's the closest I've found to an actual pub in San Francisco though I am happy to put the work in and keep looking for more. 

Lots of comfy seating. A good selection of beers though the new London Pride on draught tastes nothing like it should. There's even crisps (chips) to go with your beer which every proper pub should have. 

Great jukebox, pool table, table-football, friendly staff both behind the bar and at the door. Relaxed crowd, not too rowdy and best of all hardly any TV screens just two small, unobtrusive ones on each end of the bar.
author: Pauliee V.

description:
I miss this place when it was called CHANCES, i loved to say, screw it, let's take our chances and go to Chances, natch!

This bar is kind of weird and all over the place, it has two TV's, and mostly turned to sports, but i would hardly call it a sports bar.

And then there's downstairs, spacious and evokes a lodge feel, (deer heads, et al), and a pool table and a ATM.

I used to not like this place, but somehow i kind of like it again, the staff are super friendly, even had free pizza at happy hour lst friday! Oh, and $1.50 Tecates at happy hour that lasts till 7pm.
author: wayne s.

description:
What a nice place with a great atmosphere. Wide range of bar goers in here making it quite relaxed without the stench of hipster or douchebagism. 

Will come again!
author: Oz B.

description:
Tornado Foosball Table and Arrogant Bastard (not me) on tap for only four dollars. 

Main area kinda packed but place has a good vibe.

Also two pool tables.
author: Allan R.

description:
Except for the fact that they always kick my buddy Cal Santos out, I kind of dig this place. Chances, the bar before The Page was the same - neighborhoody, friendly, central, basic, spacious, never-too-crowded mid-town bar.

Nothing fancy but thats a given. Other than the arrogant bar staff, its a decent neighborhood haunt.
author: Greg R.

description:
After going here about 20 or 30 times so far, I've decided to give it 5 stars. Owner Bob does a great job. All the barstaff plus the locals are friendly. The windows are tinted dark; it's my kind of seedy joint.
Check out the website for Tuesday tasting sessions. Last week was tequila, oh boy!
author: Ed R.

description: Animals on the wall, check. Secret nook in the corner near the piss, check. Drunk friends, quadruple check. Time for some fun! I like this place. I'll say that. It's kind of fun because it keeps on going. This is our go-to spot before and after shows at the independent. Good selection of beers on hand and there is usually space to camp out and hang. I don't know why we picked that side room, but it had seats (kegs) and it was dark so I didn't have to look at my friend Josh anymore. SORRY JOSH
author: Erik U.

description: I dropped by here with a friend for some drinks after dinner on a Friday. The place was packed. One you got in past the mob at the door though, it wasn't that bad. They had some really good drink specials ($8.50 for an Old Speckled Hen on nitro and a Bushmills) and some really great English beers that I don't see on a regular basis. I also thoroughly enjoyed the tiny men's room hidden behind a wall.
author: Peter V.

description:
I live near The Page so it's cool in that sense.  It has the feeling of a dive bar but for a place to be a dive bar, Pabst Blue Ribbon has to be under 3 dollars.    

I was impressed by the human turnout.  I was there at 9 PM on a Monday and it was quite full.  Nevertheless I'll be coming here often.
author: Dan B.

description:
Oh they have my Boddingtons.  The Page has become a proper rival to The Fly now especially if I am just looking for a drink. 

Maybe it was the juke box playing blues for five straight songs or the weird old guy that helped my roommate on with her scarf as we were leaving but this place has just the right amount of authentic dive for a dive bar.  I look forward to a return trip in the future.  You know when I am feeling adventurous and want to go outside the five block radius of my home :)
author: Alexis B.

description: Great neighborhood bar. A deer head in the back room, plus foosball and pool.  Divisadero street used to be a no man's land, dividing lower and upper haight, but there seemed to be many more hipsters there than before.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
guy to girl ratio is empowering and it beats going all the way to man jose 
just remember, quality not quantity...
author: Shirley L.

description:
Sometimes I forget this is a destination bar, and since it's, what, three yards away, I sometimes roll up in what could constitute as PJs. But no matter. It's not the see and be seen kind of place. It's the chill with your friends in comfy seats by the window looking out on the neighborhood, or relax by yourself over a cheap glass of wine at the bar watching a game on the little tvs-- kind of place. On weekdays. 

 At the same time, you want a little more out of you night-- like a friday or saturday-- you can roll up with a whole crew, put a few bills in the jukebox to create the perfect playlist, take over the back room and drink beers and play pool to your heart's content. 

For me though, I like to meet my boyfriend after work (on a weekday), after already changing into comfy sweats and tshirt and have a few beers... then stumble on home.
author: Nina H.

description:
Like a refined 500 Club.

The Page is a welcoming environment that coaxes the neighborhoodies, alcoholics, the psuedo-alcoholics, and the bar lovers into its friendly confines.

The chairs are silly comfy and there is plenty of small tables as well as a large bar.  The staff is super approachable and fast.  The jukebox is nice as well as the pool tables.  The beer selection is pretty diverse and they pour some one-eyed drinks too.  The crowd runs the gamut.  One thing that could be said is that they are all friendly.

Word of warning...it will be packed on the weekends.  Hit it after work on a weekday to get the full effect and a chance to fall for a good neighborhood bar.

One last thing...bathrooms are small but not a diverbaresque as the 500 Club (read 1/2 the amount of puke and only 10% amount of graffiti).
author: Chris D.

description:
I'm new to the lower haight hood. I finally got a chance to pop into this place before heading off to the Galactic show and the Independent. So far I liked what I saw, dark like a good divey bar should be.  However, unlike a "real" dive bar they actually have a good selection of microbrews. 

I was already 2-sheets to the wind and only enhanced my buzz by drinking a Racer 5...yum! I'll have to come back for a full recon mission. Then we'll see how divey it can really be ;-)
author: isaias J.

description:
Been wanting to go to this place ever since I moved here and told my friend Page about it. And I'm glad I finally went. It's on my street, afterall. 

Chill atmosphere, decent jukebox...a little crowded, but still comfortable. I like the different sections and levels and pool table in the downstairs pit area.

Kind of felt like I was in the galley of a ship here, due to the shape and interior. Or maybe I just drank too much and started swaying back and forth. Either way, it was a great time and I'd definitely go back. 

A friend told me this place used to be called "Chances" which is another great name for a bar, or for a middle-aged singles event night with shots of tequila on special. Or for a cat.
author: Kelly R.

description:
They have pear cider on tap but the bathrooms are super tiny.  The jukebox was irritating until they started playing some Bill Withers and then I fully said "AWWWWWWW hellz YAH mah ninjas!"  Seemed to be a higher than average ratio of drunk marina types (note to guys: wearing a shirt that says "Tail Chaser" means you have a small penis) and I have to say that the heavier set girl exposing her breasts on purpose and stumbling drunkenly was a source of trainwreck entertainment to all my comrades and myself.  
However, it bears mention that we didn't stay at the Page...we rolled to the Amber and REALLY ended the night!
author: Jill D.

description:
I'm very thankful this place is under new management.  Back in the days when this was "Chances", a very drunk friend of mine accidentally knocked a beer into the foosball table and was subsequently kicked out.  Not kicked out for the beer, but kicked out for turning over the foosball table in a fit of rage when told to stop playing ("it's a rainy day at Wembley!").  The blind roundhouse kicks in the general direction of the bouncers didn't help either.

Needless to say, I wasn't too keen on showing my face around here for awhile (guilt by association).  But now that it is under new management, I feel like I have a new lease on life.  

Great general vibe.  Pool tables, foosball, and jukebox  - you name it.  Strong cocktails and Shiner Bock on tap!
author: Cully W.

description:
I almost feel obligated to give this bar 5 stars, seeing as though it's my local dive, and I used to go there several times a week.  The truth of the matter is, I went there for as long as I did, and never got a hook up.  The occassional dollar off here and there, but for a loyal patron you'd think they'd throw me a bone here and there.  But NO!  Hrumph!
Honestly though, some of my favorite people bartend and man the door of this establishment, and they do have a sweet fooseball table and 2 pool tables.  Not too shabby.
author: Max M.

description:
I don't frequent many bars not within walking distance but this one was worth the trip. The decor was .... well, interesting and the bar was darkly lit enough where you don't feel bad for ordering perhaps one more whiskey soda than you should. They have an internet juke box so you will never be without your favorite early-90s anthem-o-angst. The Page has plenty of seating and the staff is fine with you re-arranging the tables to suit your needs. Also amazing, they let you eat food from the delicious mexican restaurant nextdoor while you enjoy a beer from fairly diverse selection of beers on tap. 

Sadly they don't take credit cars, minus one star.
author: Rachael W.

description: I'd really like to like this bar more, but the problem is that the service is slow, and it kinda smells funny in there. I know it's a bar, but there is such a thing called Febreze, you know. The crowd are okay, I suppose, a lot of B&T folks at the weekend.
author: Mi M.

description: Funky little bar but nice.  Bartender and bouncer were friendly.  Fair prices.
author: Sara V.

description:
I don't know who is more unpretentious the bartenders or the patrons. I go to this bar on the regular and have never gotten so much as a dirty look. They serve decent sized glasses of Jameson and have an excellent draught beer selection. No matter how busy it is it is never too hard to get a pool table or play some foosball. 

My only complaints would be their lack of drink specials and refusal to accept credit cards. It is strange to me so many bars are cash only because when they accept credit cards I tend to spend at least twice as much.

I recommend the Page to any neighbors or locals looking for a relaxed experience in a place that looks like bar anywhere. I only have one funny story from this place, a friend and I went in on a Sunday night and as we entered Abba's Dancing Queen was playing. A strange song for the Page, even stranger was that it played six more times in a row, I shit you not. We drank our PBR and then ordered a shot feeling like we wanted to leave but having no where better to go to
author: Evan O.

description:
Alright, I'll admit it, we stopped off at The Page after a loooong night of bar crawling and many many vodka gimlets. I loved this place for the decor, first. It reminded me of an old bar that hadn't changed in a really long time. Another cool aspect, the chairs by the window! 

Only bad thing, the space in the front of the bar, very minimal. I didn't even make it to the back, but I think they have pool tables back there! Definitely want to go back soon.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Love this place! Laid back and cool, large whiskey and draft beer selection. Bonus points for it being right down the street!
author: Allison S.

description: Great beer list for a tiny bar.  Cool old school chairs. Absolutely horrid Marina trash ruined what could of been a cool night out.  I it weren't for the marque, I swore I was at the Tipsy Pig. Ugh, maybe happy hour before they all come out of their pods next time.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I went here for the first time last night. I'm surprised I've never been here before since I've been to The Fly many many times. Last night was pretty crowded (Saturday night) and they have one of their pool tables right in the middle of the room by the bar. This makes the area crowded and inconvenient for those drinking or playing pool.

Down a few stairs there is another pool table and a foosball table. The bar has a divey feel and animal heads decorating the walls. I liked it. I think I would really like it on a week night or basically anytime that it's not that crowded. I'll definitely be going back. Maybe after grabbing a happy hour drink and pizza at The Fly.
author: Jackie G.

description: This is a true neighborhood bar. By that I mean that people from all over drop in - doesn't matter how you dress, what your race or ethnicity is, or any thing else that might set you apart - the Page is just a cool pub to relax with pool tables, fooseball, many beers, and a cool staff. Don't be fooled by some marina idiots who wander in later in the night. The staff can't control that. Bob Wait, the owner, and his entire crew at the bar are awesome people who make you feel at home. Go there and give it a shot.
author: Edward N.

description:
This is the first SF bar I ever visited and I am still coming back. Reasons I love the Page:

1. Pool tables
2. Photo Hunt
3. Juke Box
4. It's neighborhood feeling on weeknights
5. It's in my neighborhood
6. Good people watching
7. Awesome bartenders
8. Strong drinks
9. I have been known to walk the wrong way home after good nights here.

Do it, but don't make it so crowded I have to remove stars.
author: Alicia J.

description: Cheap cocktails. Cash only. Dive bar.  Exactly what you would expect.
author: Athena W.

description: I adore The Page and have been coming here for years. Though it seems to be developing into a more popular bar and is sometimes significantly more crowded than in olden days, I'd still rank it as one of my favorite bars in SF. Service here is quick, and there's a huge selection of both draft and bottled beers, a few of which rotate occasionally.  Plentiful seating makes it pretty easy to find somewhere to enjoy your drink.  Definitely a good spot to check out if you're in the area and haven't been before.
author: Tim A.

description:
Been here dozens of times with friends. It's a stones throw from my house.  They have sometimes have interesting beers that you don't find everywhere.
Also they have stiff drinks to boot and a couple pool tables. Some interesting old "Sea Dog" paintings on the wall make it feel like a grandpa house. I can dig it...
author: Timbo G.

description:
The Page has quickly become my de facto surrogate Chicago Corner Bar (see Ten Cat). The Jameson and PBR flow just as freely, the staff is just as friendly and the crowd is just as diverse and unpretentious.

And they don't look at me crosseyed when I read at the bar.

Why is The Page such an anomoly in this city?
author: Don Q.

description:
I like that *this* neighborhood bar does not charge locals a cover charge. 

Madrone you blew it.
author: Amelia L.

description: A good dive bar. Crowded on Saturday nights, but a good time regardless.
author: Katie M.

description: Ah The Page... I only have one fleeting memory of you but in Yelpland, that's enough to write a review (but you don't need to read it).
