It was the 10th of December and the 3rd day of Twelve Drinking Days of Christmas. The rules state that you must have 1 drink at the designated bar during designated "happy hours". I got trapped at work until about 6:30pm and had a massage appointment at 7:00pm. Given rush hour traffic through downtown, I knew time was not on my side. But, if there is a will, there is a way. I zipped through town, parked my car in an illegal spot, ran into The Page, ordered a shot of tequila, threw it back, hugged a few loved ones, and then like a shot of lightning through the dark, I was gone! 1 pt for me, bitches! And the tequila, well, tasted like tequila.
author: Susan L.

description:
Great place to hang out.
People are fun and friendly (DOUCHE BAG FREE)
every time i go, i usually have a great time
drinks are great.
but I ADMIT, guys have a hard time getting drinks sometimes! (witness)
two pool tables, sometimes crowded but always fun!
author: Tipay C.

description: Oh the Page. I love you. I miss dive bars in the south and of any I've found in SF the Page reminds me the most of my favorite haunts of the past. Maybe its just the Abita on tap and Lonestar in the bottles but I feel at home here. It gets super crowded, and I'm often here on weeknights when it gets busy, but this place has a magical power to suck you in until 2am no matter what time you arrive and what time you plan to leave. Always a stop when I'm on Divis whether its a big night out or drinks with a friend.
author: Kelli F.

description:
Interesting mix of people: Drunks, hipsters, workers, DINKYs, neighborhood folk, haggard and pretty, young and oldish.

Not too sceney, good beer, and minimal attitude.

Weekends get packed and sweaty and it's kinda hard to get a drink.
author: Whit P.

description:
Went here rather late on a Sunday.  Place was actually full until closing.  It is small but has a large pool room in the back where you can have a seat and have a conversation.  

Wasn't there for long but really enjoyed my time there.  People were a mixture.  Bartender was friendly and the drinks were good.  I will definitely go back the next time that I am in the area.
author: Ralph S.

description:
Great   Mon-Thur   bar for anyone in the neighborhood. I love the decor, the highway Motel/ 60's dive bar feeling. I especially dig the paintings, old ships, sea captains, and Henry the VIII above the pool table. Very nice bartenders who will actually remember you only after a few visits. 

Weekends get a little crowded and the bar takes on a different vibe. Not as fun as on weekdays.

Interesting people watching opportunities, good beer, drink choices, and Soccer-On-A-Stick! 

I wish the jukebox wasn't one of the electronic/downloadable song jukeboxes...it kind of takes away from the hip factor.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
I love the fact that my living room has a foosball table, a pool table and lots of trophy heads all around. I have books painted on the wall and a door to nowhere. I have cheap drinks and bartenders with just enough grit to make me come back. I'm the luckiest guy on Page St.

Oh wait, Im sorry, Im thinking of The Page, my bad.
author: Big W.

description: Casual cool crowd kind of bar, with $4 drinks!! Definitely a good reason to go out on Divisadero.
author: Erin J.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the city - perfect for weeknight pool and conversation or weekend frivolity. 

The bar is dive-ish, the crowd varies depending on the night, one pool table is located inconveniently in an almost-hallway, and there are a wide range of beers available. These things magically combine to make The Page one great bar.
author: Abigail R.

description:
I have only been to The Page once so far, yet my experience there was one that was very much enjoyed. The beers were delicious and properly priced, the interior decor and ambiance were wonderful, and the patrons were (generally) fun. The pool table in the back was a nice standard to see as well. 

The eclectic style and decent prices make The Page a fun dive that I'll definitely have to visit again.
author: Aaron J.

description:
The first few times I walked by The Page, I thought it was like the kind of old timers bar that my grandfather used to haunt in Detroit. It's got a weather-worn, blue collar vibe to it, and there were some pretty shady dudes hanging out who looked like they could body double for Charles Bukowski.

It was only when I went inside that I realized that this place is only seedy in an ironic, disaffected hipster way, which is usually pretty annoying, but in the case of The Page I'm definitely smitten. It's cozy, it's pretty chill (except for one Saturday when girls were literally dancing on tables. Dancing on tables! Who does that anymore?), and I had the best vodka martini of my life there once, for like $5. Highly recommended as a place to drink like you just got laid off from the Ford plant.
author: Melissa J.

description:
Not a bad place with full bar, cute friendly barstaff, fun internet jukebox . . 

it would earn 2 more stars from me if they ditched the TVs.
author: Carlos C.

description:
Comfortable, dim, and not horribly crowded, this is a chill bar to stop in for a drink.

If you're looking for foosball, don't look here.  Last time I was there, the Tornado table was in terrible condition, and filled with a mix of red sticky balls (good) and white smooth balls (awful.)  Blargh.
author: Caryn K.

description:
Def on of the better dive bars in SF... it's got almost everything you would want in a standard chill, dive..... pool table... foosball... deers heads...low lighting... hidden coves to kick it... decently stiff drinks .... pretty good jukebox ... 
What's more to need .... 
oh wait .. pinball would be the capper for me :P
author: Jeremy R.

description:
The Page is the quintessential neighborhood bar where pretty much everyone feels welcomed. I just wish it didn't get so crowded on weekend nights... I mean, it's not THAT great.

Well, that little secret room is pretty great, but beyond that, eh...
author: Trey F.

description: Excellent little local dive. 2 pool tables and a foosball table in back, but people use the area around the pool tables, which can make it difficult for a game. Good crowd. Cash only sucks, but if you know going in you can deal.
author: Monika M.

description: if you want to get a little piss drunk before you head back over the bay bridge and into the oakland airport  this is the place to be. weird crowd but good drinks. on your way out try to take a bag of potato chips that are behind the bar, i dare you.  ah.
author: Joel D.

description:
A great neighborhood bar.  The Page trusts it's patrons with musical guidance (jukebox). Surprisingly, with this crowd it works in their favor.  I only have two complaints:

1- foosball table balls are too heavy and slow.
2- additional speakers are needed in the back area.
author: Peter S.

description:
Pros:
This place reminds me of a old hotel lounge bar from the early 60's that never realized it was not in fact the 60's anymore. It's a dive bar. Great place to meet up with friends for a casual drink PLUS I can walk from my place. 
Door guy is always nice.
Cons: 
The  boy's basketball locker room smell I have to get used to every time I walk in. And it gets way too crowded.
author: liz L.

description:
I really like the Page! The decor is great; it's a little similar to that of the Hemlock on Polk in the TL (kind of rustic, with deer head plaques and raccoon art), but it's got less of a rock & roll vibe. I definitely prefer to come here during off-nights or off-peak hours, though. Went once when it was crowded and the whole atmosphere changed...went from being quiet and Twin Peaks-y to being another hipster hub.

There are pool tables downstairs, a smallish women's room, and plenty of places to sit - again, provided you go at the right time. Nice, cheap PBR, too.
author: Heidi G.

description: My excursions here have been hit and miss.  There's a poll table in the back, which is nice.  Can get busy, and the path in front of the bar is kind of narrow, making it increasingly awkward to move around when it's busy.  Agree with the other reviewers that the sound system kind of sucks.
author: Andy B.

description:
5 stars for when it isn't too crowded and I can play photohunt.  3 stars for when it is too crowded and I can't play photohunt.  All the bartenders seem really nice and efficient.  I would give it 10 stars if they replaced one of the pool tables with Pop a shot basketball but I bet a lot of people would not agree with me.

I just put it down to 3 stars becuase I never get to play photohunt.

*****UPDATE**** ok I will change it to 4.  I went after work the other day and it was nice and not too crowded, a relaxed crowd of people watching the giants game.  Also, I realized that they had a great, large selection of liquor. which is always good...
author: b s.

description:
A nice little dark bar with pool tables, foosball and an internet jukebox. Unfortunately, it gets crowded with douchebags later on at night. 

Come and leave early to avoid the a-holes.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Pretty much a regular neighborhood bar that pleasingly serves me Myers and Coke in a full sized glass. Not too much rum, definitely not too much coke, yay!

Good place to hang out with friends. Totally worth the extra two block walk from my house compared to Madrone (although my distaste for Madrone has diminished some).

I've never been there on the weekend... Correction: I have now been there on a weekend. My was it crowded. Does anybody else remember when  the Page WASN'T popular?
author: Noah R.

description:
The Page is by far the best bar in this neighborhood. However, it's probably best to avoid this place on the weekends. When The Page fills up it's not the most comfortable place to be. The jukebox offers a decent collection of music, the drinks are fairly cheap, and the staff is mostly friendly.  

If you're down with cozy warm wallpaper and taxidermy deer heads, you're down with The Page.
author: Laura L.

description:
There's nothing like ending your night right at the Page - an abundance of different draft beers, friendly locals, and attentive bar tenders makes this bar stand out.  

You gotta respect a bar that carries Arrogant Bastard Ale on draft - one of my favs! Keep it up, Page!
author: Scott G.

description:
cool bar. it was a little odd that is was so crowded near the front, yet empty near the back. then again, it's not that strange because the bar was in the front :) they have a solid jukebox selection with a bunch a newer songs(always a plus IMO). the bouncer was cool, although i hate that he carded me when i was coming back from a smoke-break. 

the bartenders were nice and poured some stiff drinks. i love when i order a cranberry/vodka, and it is pink-colored(a sign that it is merely vodka with a splash of cranberry). the bathroom was kinda ghetto, but that's fine with me as long as i dont need to take a shit. although i get freaked out when the stall and urinal are next to each other, as i cant "perform" under pressure. 

the pool table is always a plus, although it was impossible to get in a game. and college basketball on the tv's is a-ok with me. plenty of tables and seats. good spot in a good neighborhood. great choice for dyl.
author: Andrew T.

description: I've lived in the Divis corridor for about 4 years, and I don't know what it is, but the bars on this strip are a drag. There's something especially irksome about the Page. A dive bar should never, ever, ever have carpet! After two steps, I feel like I should hose off my shoes. And two steps is all you get, because the place is laid out so that it's impossible to walk through with side stepping, even on a quiet night. There is a good selection, bartenders are attentive, and the drinks are reasonably priced, but I never want to stay and enjoy them because the vibe is so off. Kind of like how it smells a little off (I did mention the carpet, right?).
author: Wayne W.

description:
Fun, upbeat music and a lively crowd. Pool tables, multiple levels and a jukebox set it apart from most SF bars. Overall a great little bar that I'd be happy to visit again.

Of course, Arrogant Bastard on tap always wins brownie points with me, too.
author: Jay U.

description: Ahhhhh! Stay far away. This isn't even dive bar cool. It's just not cool. Drinks are nasty. Go anywhere else. Even Zeitgeist.
author: Emily M.

description:
This is a great bar.  It's small enough to be friendly but large enough to meet some diverse people.  Free pizza at the Monday happy hour at the end of the bar.  
Saturday night isn't so busy you can't move, but it's got a great atmosphere nonetheless.  Go now, in fact, I think every day is good there. Especially if you like Fernet.
author: George S.

description:
This place is alright. 
There are pool tables, foosball, red leather seats, liquor and beer + half decent jukebox.
author: Chris T.

description: Okay crowd, Okay manhattan... meh... thats all I have to say about that
author: c e.

description:
This place sucks.  I've never been to a place where the employees try to start fights with the patrons.  It's a shame that a place that could be some what cool, has to hire an ass to check ID's at the door.  He tried to start a fight with 10 people. First off that's dumb on his part and also pretty lame representation of that bar. There was no need for him to say anything to us but he insisted on the name calling.  Real bully like.  If the owners of this establishment had any cares in the world for their bar to stay afloat they would rid themselves of the waste of space that mans the front door.  Unprofessional.   
You lost yourself a loyal patron.  Fire the fat guy and your stars may rise.
author: Dominic P.

description: I've come here twice in the past month and it's generally fun until something goes sour very suddenly and very fast. The first time, it was the watery greyhound and the bartender that refused to admit it -- or much less do anything about it. The second time we were seriously put off by a pathetic group of condescending and pretentious locals who monopolized the pool table and made up rules on the spot, haha. Good times. If I could be moved to care, I would have been quite aggravated. Fortunately, our group was fun and the place sufficed, but it's nothing beyond just OK, the cash-only policy is outdated, and the crowd leaves a lot to be desired. There's simply better out there and The Page has exhausted its benefit of the doubt.
author: G. J.

description:
used to be my hangout until i moved to the mission...

i love it but times have changed... it's much different now on wknds so be warned.  Stick to the week days...
author: Vinh N.

description: I am all for dark and divey bars but this one smelled like urine in the back area and there was nowhere you could be without getting poked with a pool stick.  The crowd was diverse but not in a way that I would call good.
author: Seong P.

description: I thought this place was super cute.  It's fairly small, and not incredibly ideal for people with a big party (like we had), but I still liked the spot.  It has a dark nostalgic kind of feel.  Definitely a throwback old-style bar...wood walls with animal heads hanging around, comfy 60's looking leather chairs, pool tables under hanging lamps, the classic looking bar...it gave the place a really cool vibe.  Also--for a Saturday night, I never had to wait more than 5 minutes to have a bartender take and fill my drink order--which is pretty amazing.  The people around were pretty decent, didn't seem like any sort of specific crowd.  We made a night at the page, and it seemed like a good spot...but it's also super close to a lot of other cool bars.  So if you just walk by and see the neon sign, I would recommend popping in.
author: Courtney H.

description: Reliably good cocktails at nice recessionista pricing. Close to other great stops in the 'hood. This unassuming bar is a great stop!
author: Lorna M.

description:
this place has never done me wrong.  its a friendly neighborhood bar with a dimly lit interior and old school decorations.  old school meaning 'west virginia' - for example, there are deerheads everywhere and velvet paintings of deers frolicking lovely-like in a happy forest setting.  i suppose one could take this to be both a celebration of life and death.  the portrait of the happy deer... and... then... the stoic yet fragile deerhead preserved in its true to life form.  reminding us all that we are but grains of sand on an infinite beach in this maddening and fascinating thing we call life.  

they also have pool tables, which is awesome and a fantastic selection of  beers including frambozen, the brew the infamous gil turned me onto.  i am also under the impression that ghosts haunt this place.  man, is it just me or is this review weird? i might as well start listing random items in dadaist fashion and spelling out my gutteral grunts instead of trying to form words.  its mostly due to the fact that i've been having communication breakdowns lately.  i've been misunderstood and judged wrongly.  i assume too much and take for granted that most people will 'get it' when really they won't.  

such is life.  frambozen rules.
author: Karen K.

description: Really fanfuckingtastic neighborhood bar.  Killer selection of draught beers, decor out of some weird 70's living room, SOUL music on the jukebox and a few displays of fine taxidermy.
author: Rob G.

description:
the guys really do outnumber the gals by like 10 to 1 ratio here. so if you're a guy looking to hook up, why even bother? go to hemlock instead. and if you're a gal, remember it's the quality, not the quantity. now if you're just interested in getting a drink, page is a decent place for that. solid drinks and for the most part, friendly bartenders. however, with madrone, fly and even toronado all within a few blocks, i just can't imagine going to page these days, unless i'm meeting people for a drink, and if they're paying.

another thing, it annoys the hell out of me when a bar like page calls itself "the page." the word "the" should be reserved for only the best bars in the city. page isn't one of them.

"the" worthy bars
-----------------
the bar on castro
the stud
the attic club
el rio

there's probably a lot more, but my brain is going dead right now.
author: frisco j.

description: Attended my first DYL Tour event this past Friday at the Page.  Now, I don't know if it was the Page itself that led to the great time or the fellow Yelpers, but I am more than willing to return.  Extra points for being walking/stumbling distance to my house.  I see major potential that this could become my favorite neighborhood bar.  Oh, and it got thumbs up from the boyfriend...and he's the "neighborhood joint" expert.
author: Jessica W.

description: Stout drinks and a great jukebox...need I say more?
author: Todd E.

description: What a cool place!  Stumbled on over here from Bar Fly with Jay after our book exchange and beers.  Good selection of beers on tap, including Arrogant Bastard Ale.  If you follow my reviews, which you dont, you would know that ABA holds a special place in my heart.  My visit was on a Saturday afternoon, and the bar stools were about half occupied.  Great time to go since you can chat with the bartenders and other patrons.  Everyone was friendly and interesting.  Ill go back.
author: Martin S.

description: Please don't go to this bar. It's my bar. Go home frat boy. Just kidding. Sort of. I hate when it's football night and the meatheads and meat-ettes pour in to get sloppy drunk as if it's the Fishbowl. I much prefer the more low-key vibe. Gawd-bless the bartenders who recognize the regulars, and well...serve us first. :)
author: Trinity M.

description: Page adds to the list of all the neighbourhood bar.. We usually go after work.. and both of the staff Rebecca and Laila are very friendly and good. Very good for late weekday nights. Good prices too.
author: Shradha K.

description: Came here for a nightcap after a long night out with the team, wasn't too impressed, but then again, not really my kind of place.  Deer tapestries and 20+ beers on tap doesn't exactly equal a good time in my book.  I tried something different - a beer that I chose at random from the taps.  I think it was called "Intrigue" or something shifty like that.  All in all, a nice place to end the night with friends.  And Fernet?  No thanks....
author: Sam P.

description: The Page is one of the least pretentious bars in this city. No dance floor, the pool tables are too close to the walls, everything is dim and covered in old carpet. Fucking. Perfect. My only wish is that there was some 200 year old sea captain posted up at the corner of the bar spouting mermaid stories, and the legend of his wooden dick. Instead they have a video poker machine.
author: Rob D.

description: If you are a chump, prick, preppy or total douche then you will love The Page. It was a lot cooler when it was Chance's and it wasn't even cool then. We used to say going there was "taking your Chance's" (i know it's not funny). The pool tables are uneven. The TV's are always on. The internet juke box is obnoxious. The bartenders are hit and miss. I have to admit a few of them are cool. The drinks are pricy and most of all, the scene SUCKS.  A good place to do some coke and throw up.
author: Kyle J.

description: Oh the Page. Definitely the easiest bar on Divisadero. Best for locals for weeknights - weekends seem to attract a different cliente. Very wide ranging beer selection, reasonably priced. Nice old school pub tables for sitting and having legit group conversations. Back room with the pool table, foosball usually has open places to sit if its busy. Stinky carpet that reminds me of my Grandpa's basement 20 years ago.
author: Adam V.

description: I really wish I lived closer to The Page.  I ended up here randomly after having dinner across the street and it's just such a great bar.  I knew I was going to like it from the moment the bouncer struck up a conversation with me, complimenting me on my Obama button AND my coat.  A good man, no doubt!  The Page has good beer on tap, good tunes on the jukebox, and a friendly, unpretentious staff.  The night I was there, the clientèle was cool too-- very chill, young, but not too young crowd.  The place is huge, with two pool tables and foosball if you are so inclined.  I watched Michael Phelps win his 8th gold medal here and I can't think of too many other places I'd have rather been (except Beijing maybe :)  I just wish they took credit cards...
author: Kristin P.

description: It's close to my house and it gets the job done. What more is there to say? If you ever want to go drinking at the Page call me up and I'll meet you there.
author: Laura D.

description: This is a great neighborhood bar with a good selection of beer, two pool tables, friendly locals and bartenders, and the most honest staff I have ever encountered in a city.  I left a brand new black cashmere scarf there about 2 weeks ago. After forgetting to call them, I wrote it off as gone by the third day.  I finally made it back this past Thursday with some friends and thought, "what the hell...I'll at least ask." Sure enough, they had held on to it for me.
author: k. w.

description: This place is a great neighborhood bar. It definitely covers the spectrum. Where else can you have someone sipping 209 gin and tonic with pinky in the air while the guy next to him is sipping Pabst from the tap? I ordered the 21A watermelon wheat beer the last time I was here. It comes in a can, and to be honest I was kinda embarrassed to be drinking beer from a can... at a bar. I think the cute bartender picked up on this and offered me a glass so I could pour my beer into it. At that point I knew this place rocked!
author: Brian A.

description: I'd give this five stars, but the drinks are just *slightly* over-priced and on the weekends it gets jammed with people that I never see there on the weeknights. But, yeah, if you live in the area the Page is the best place to catch a beer on a Wednesday night. It's relaxing like peeing in the shower.
author: Jake S.

description:
Someone could make an interesting case study of the 3 bars housed in victorians on Divisadero St- Lions Pub, Madrone, and the Page.  
I'd seen the page on many trips down Divisadero, but never stumbled in until a month ago.  The exterior and signs looks vintage or maybe even run-down.  Turns out, that is part of the charm, rather than a draw-back.
Now that I live nearby, its a go-to for a low key night, great for conversation or billiards or foos ball.  
Not scene-y, but a good eclectic crowd.  Most draughts are 4.50, the staff is patient, and the music has always been a nice variety.  
I especially like that the place moody wall paper, low lighting, dark bar gives it a cozy, victorian feel.  Similar to Lions Pub, but without the pomp and circumstance and fruity drinks.  This a relaxed pub, likely to induce conversations with grad students, and not a place to get into brawls or have a hot night out.
author: Christian W.

description: Another great dive.  I drink ketel one & soda so, I can't really say anything about the cocktails, they make a great ketel/soda.  My friend says they do a great dirty martini.  It's just a good wind down (up?) spot for after a show at the indy on a random Tuesday...  or whenver.
author: Emily T.

description: This place has some potential. And oddly enough, it's new name happens to be "The Page." Cool name for a bar, with one of those cool, newfangled internet jukeboxes (no Led Zeppelin, though I'm disappointed to say) and a pool table in the lower level. I was here during the day on a pub crawl so I'll have to go back at night and see if it's swingin'.
author: Michael E.

description: I like this bar in spite of the carpet (why?) and the charmless, dead, machine-like eyes of the bartenders.  Although I do admire the bartenders' unrelenting cheerlessness and the way that I get absolutely hammered every time I go there even if I only have one drink (how?).
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: Ole faithful...the Page never let's me down.  It's the "neighborhood" bar where you're most likely to run into people you know.  Great jukebox, pool table, foosball (sp?), and friendly bartenders.  I used to come here all the time and I'm feeling this void in my life...I think I need to go to the Page.  Pete J. (aka Mayor of WAMA) when is the next town meeting??
author: Michelle L.

description: A friendly place to jump in and have some real Californian Ale and some easy random talk with traveling actresses, socialist feminists or linguistics GI Joes at the bar, or just to organize a spontaneous quick foosball championship for the night over the billiard table.  Beware, they have the Tornado table, not the Garlando I've used to play overseas.
author: Tamas K.

description:
great place. 

the fooseball table is awesome, except when people take the balls with them when they go outside to smoke.
author: Amanda M.

description: At first this place seemed cooler. Upon entering and ordering a vodka gimlet I was pleased to see the juicer come out and add freshly squeezed lime juice to my drink! the upstairs was a bit narrow though and it was hard to stand up there with a group. We went down to the fooseball table to hang out and play. Again it soon became a bit too crowded, people needed to get to the ATM machine which was sort of behind the fooseball table and therefore interrupting our group of friends. Then all of a sudden it got ridiculously crowded and no one could comfortably play pool let alone fooseball. The crowd was on the young side - if you're into that. It might be OK to come in for happy hour or something but sat night was a bit cramped for a bar that seems like it has chill intentions.
author: Lindsay A.

description: This is my neighborhood bar.  The crowd is mostly tourists on Th, Fr, Sa, but during the week it's way more relaxed.  Good for pool, chatting.  Jukebox is on or else there's no music.  The bartenders and bouncers are really nice.  Tends to be the go-to bar when the independent closes.
author: Neil G.

description: In all the years I lived up the street, I desperately hoped that if Chances ever went out of business, someone (like me) would buy it and name it "Second Chances." Unfortunately, they sure didn't.
author: Megan W.

description:
A mix between a sports bar and a dive bar.two pool tables in the back and sports playing in the front. Unfortunately I think we came on an understaffed night. It took my date a good 10+ minutes of waiting for a drink, and 3 of me interjecting on her behalf to get a drink. On the very positive side the place does have an oatmeal stout on tap, so my tummy was very happy.

Unfortunately this bar is cash only. While that is not uncommon, it is still unfortunate. A pretty decent date place, but expect to be heckled if you are making out in the corner.
author: H B.

description: Basically the page is my favorite bar. It's dressed up as a dive, but it has a really nice liquor selection. Like, there are tons of flavored premium vodkas for the reformed marina girl in all of us. 2 pool tables, foozeball, and pink lights, what more could you ask for?
author: Roseanne W.

description: Y'know those places...the ones to see and be seen, this isn't one of them. It is a place to get a drink, play some pool and order something up on the internet capable jukebox. So, if you've just come down from the high of a great shopping spree and can't wait to show off your new---whatever, go somewhere else. If you're looking to hang out with your friends, get a little buzzed and stumble home, you've just found your spot.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I love the Page! I just love the way it looks! It's a great early evening bar!
author: Amy E.

description: Good drinks and I think the bartenders are really cool. They don't get uptight when it gets crazy busy and they don't make mistakes. I like pool and I like the decor here it's a comfortable hangout. The patrons are hit or miss. I've encountered downright hostility....from Brits and Americans...oddly enough...and also have met some authentic long time San Franciscans such as yours truly and had one (upper B list) celebrity sighting: Amy Poehler. Does get a bit too crowded at times. With a little bit of room to breathe and a good crowd it comes highly recommended.
author: Steve P.

description: Two pool tables and a juke box.  Beer and cocktails.  No one pretty so I don't have to dress up.  Lots of friendly, chatty folks--I've met new friends here on more than one occasion.  Good pool players without the pretense.  Great place to hang out.
author: Nicci S.

description: My butthole still hurts from the no credit card register ring. Lame.
author: C. Grant M.

description: Good jukebox with a nice selection of beers on tap. Fortunately, this place is open after some of the other bars close. The pool table and foosball are a nice addition, just wish I could find someone to play foosball against...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Well, what can I say it was a good night and an equally great bar. I was here last Friday with some Yelpers. I love that it's two floors and is equipped with two pool tables. The bartenders were friendly and made me one very strong vodka and tonic:-)  I will definitely return again since its soo close to home.
author: Stacy F.

description: The Page used to be a bar that I would go to every once in awhile. The people are generally cool there. However last time I went we had an overwhelmed bartender, who was clearly in a bad mood and short pouring all the shots. I watched her do a 10 count on 3 shots. I asked her bout it and she glared at me and said it was a 12 count. I hate to slam a bar for a bad night, but short pouring is a sin....
author: Tommy Y.

description:
Just divey enough.

Cheap dranks, and cute skanks
author: Ollie B.

description:
i remember when this used to be chances. i love that part in rent girl where michelle tea describes going to chances for a hooker party and although they arent in sf when that happens (and thus not at our dearly departed chances on divis), i always imagine it's the same bar and i just might see some girl from the scene slouched on a stool, fishnets torn, pushing her natty birdnested hair out of her eyes, sipping a watery gin and tonic with a bleary red mouth. 

i never do, but it always just feels so possible. it would just feel so right. 

i live right across from the page so its always my last nightcap on the way home. i love curling up here with a few shots for the night and a pint before bed. i always see people i know here, and usually invite them back to my house for a night-night nightcap --  even if they're two inches from my nose insisting i owe them money or asking if i'm the new girl in the building whos an IV drug user. cause you know, they knew where the best needle exchanges were in the city. seriously, not judging or anything. 


whatever.  if you're here on a sunday night, look for the girl with fake birds tangled in her hair, swaying to 'foxy lady' by hendrix. it might not be me, but chances are i'm close by.
author: leona ..

description: You know those days in San Francisco, there's about 100 of them, where its raining and cold and all you want to do is stay indoors and do nothing? Those are the days I want to spend at The Page, doing nothing. Hours can be wasted in here drinking (yes its cash only but we are in San Francisco after all, get over it), playing pool or Foosball (I semi-suck at the former, totally suck at the latter), or contemplating just what that creepy window by the guy's bathroom with the curtain covering it is. Comfy chairs, lots of bar space, but it does suck when its crowded.
author: sholeh m.

description: Don't be fooled. This is NOT a dive bar. That being said, for the most part, I like the Page. Nice bartenders who pour stiff drinks. The crowd can be mixed -- some nights a little overly jocky, some nights a little overly hipstery, but usually a nice balance. A little overly crowded on Fridays and Saturdays, but other nights of the week are good. It can be a bit of a sausage-fest... I'll leave it up to you to decide if that's a good or a bad thing.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Exclusively ours on my birthday, therefore a fantastic place for a private party!  Not a happening bar, but the bartenders were very accommodating (carbombs galore) and the jukebox was rocking!  Great place with friends on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Natalie E.

description:
Great bartenders, decent crowd. "where should we go tonight"...."eh, i dont know what do you feel like doing"...."not sure, lets try something new"...."ok what neighborhood"....."not sure what do you think"......"i'll do whatever"....."well it is getting late to travel to the mission"....."ya....."......."guess its the page". 

If you dont feel like figuring out where to go for a few drinks, just go to the page. Decent prices and you will most likely end up talking to everyone seated around you. Pool tables. Local watering hole. Thanks.
author: Diana D.

description: Well I've been living in SF for a month now and I have now designated this place as my local neighborhood bar.  I like the feel and ambiance to it and it doesn't hurt that they have cute friendly female bartenders working as most places should have that as a requirement.  The crowd is good although it tends to get a little meatheady at times but overall I like the place and will return to this place on a regular basis.  The only thing although it's not a huge problem is that they charge $4.50 for their cocktails where most places charge $4....so instead of leaving $5 I have to leave $6 since nobody ever takes the .50 change....I'm going to have to take that change now....will need those quarters for the bus or for laundry.
author: David C.

description: This is my local and it's a good all around bar.  They have some tv's, an mp3 juke, photo hunt, pool x2, foosball, and a handful of tables all in a relatively small space.  It's not quite the classic dive it used to be as Chance's, but still has a neighborhoody feel or maybe it's just I feel that way since I live in the nighborhood.  A new name/owner, a fresh coat of paint, small increase to drink prices and this place is now pretty happening.  It gets packed way more than it used to and I would now consider it a destination kind of bar for many as opposed a bar where you'd have a couple to start off or end your night.  Of course, you can still do that, but you can also be out and amongst a bunch of people here now as well.  On a final note, they have a full bar unlike many of the beer/wine/sake places in the lower haight.  The Page is easily my bar of choice on Divis.
author: Zach J.

description:
i have a love/hate thing going on with the page...

too many college kids but there's foosball in the back

the place smells but there's faux brick wall lining (PIMP!)

there's never cute girls in there but the bartenders are cool

im not so sure id go here if i didnt live 100 ft away but then again it's not that bad considering madrone is the other option
author: daniel c.

description: This dark and discreet hang out for locals allows for one to many Basil Handens rocks.  One more, please.
author: frankee U.

description: Oh sweet giver of whiskey, how do I love thee? Cool owner, cool bartenders, cheap drinks...Powers Whiskey represented like it should be. Bye Bye stinky Chances and hello home away from home.
author: Ham and Eggs M.

description:
the only local bar in  my hood that i'm willing to step inside, non pretentious & $5 shot of jameson's!  oh happy day :)
***************UPDATE 12/29***********************

bartender served me a shot with two chips on the glass and showed no remorse for it.  never coming back, classless sober, angry bartenders, door guy is cool though.
author: Pickle R.

description: This is a good neighborhood bar that occasionally gets too crowded.  The pool and foosball tables are nice, the drink selections are good, the bartenders average.  They occasionally have some nice special beers from Magnolia.  I probably won't be back much now that I don't live across the street, but it's a pretty good bar, if there isn't too much of a crowd.
author: Heidi P.

description: This bar is way fun on the weekdays...  foosball table, pool table, chill locals.  The weekend is another story...  Marina residents flock the bar by the taxi load and it reminds me more of a college dive bar than the local bar I love.  Either way the staff is nice and the beer is cold, not to mention only a one block stumble from my place.
author: Timmy K.

description: This was the site of my 1st official DYL event.  Rainy night and I actually found parking just up the street.  The Page is the type of neighborhood bar where you can go and unwind after a long day.  It's a little more low-key than Sutter Station...not as bright on the lights, but ample space for a crowd.  Cool web jukebox.  Foosball and pool in the rear.  And the bartenders are cool there.
author: JeFF T.

description: Solid.  Great selection of brews on tap.  Good crowd for a Thursday night.  No attitude.  A neighborhood plus bar.  They have a full bar but most folks were drinking beer - its that kind of place.  There's a pool table in the back, so you just might sink a shot in the left corner pocket.
author: Aaron T.

description:
the page is:

1.small
2.has good music(i tend  to judge things on their music)
3. has nerds w obama shirts coming on to me and my friends
4.decent drinks
author: Lauren V.

description: I tried on a complete stranger's HUGE wedding ring here once. I guess this review is more or less to preserve my grand memories. It was so sparkly!
author: Erin G.

description: ahhhhh, i'm so excited that the Page is my new neighborhood bar.   It feels instantly cozy, but not boring.  Whatever kind of night you're trying to have, the Page can provide.  it's the perfect go-to spot.  turns out there's lots to like about life in the panhandle . . .
author: Natalie S.

description:
The last time I found myself here was immediately after a friend and I got 86'ed from that other bar down the street for smoking in the bathroom and tampering with the smoke detector (in protest of the impromptu no ins-and-outs policy; can you believe it?!). The repeated pounding on the door hadn't deterred us either, we just assumed it was some dumbass, drunk and impatient coke fiend at whom we continued to yell, "SHUT THE FUCK UP!!" Actually, turns out it was the 6 foot 7 gargoyle of a bouncer and he was fucking pissed, to say the least. Hilarity ensued as we were being escorted from the bar with me trying to make a case for the lack of evidence linking us to the scene of the crime and my friend repeatedly denying her inebriation with absurd statements such as, "I could DRIVE right now if I wanted to!" In any event, towards the Page we stumbled, almost instinctively, and it welcomed us with open arms. This bar means business and business means booze. No DJ's, no dancing, no theme, no scene. Just a row of worn-out bar stools begging to be warmed. This is my kind of bar.

In a way, the Page is sort of like your lame friend's cooler older brother with the lame friend being that nearby watering hole. Your motive for hanging out with aforementioned lame friend is clear: you have a crush on her awesome older brother but he doesn't really know of or care about you. He's just there. Like maybe while your sort of lame friend is in the bathroom, you pretend to wander aimlessly down the hall pretending you're looking for her and conveniently "drop by" his room, casually "pop in" and "innocently" ask what's up. Maybe he ignores you because Metallica's on full-blast and you don't have the balls to speak up or maybe he just looks up and nods because you're his sister's totally pathetic and uncool prepubescent friend and now you're totally embarrassed and want to die. True story. Anyway, I forget how I intended to weave this analogy into my point. But back to the Page, go there.
author: Jenn W.

description: Long, skinny bar that makes it seem like more people are in there than there actually are -- but an overall good vibe in this place. The cute bartenders are some of the only girls in the place, but at least they make a good drink. If you are feeling a little claustrophobic, make your way to the pit in the back and play some foosball.
author: Chris L.

description: This bar is my living room.  I've been going here since Hank and Sean were the owners and you could smoke.  I have albums of birthday party pix by the pool table.  They have your typical selection of beer and hard liquor.  I would say it's the best bar in the middle Haight.  Just remember, CASH ONLY.
author: Amy H.

description: Racer 5 on tap and a pimp at the bar.  No really, a pimp...  Like Huggybear.
author: Tony A.

description: Better during the week.  Too many people during the weekend, but great neighborhood place.
author: stefan d.

description: Ah Le Page... What can I say except the juke box is always broken, and thats the highlight.
author: Adam L.

description: I just moved to San Fran and live in Alamo Square Park and I found the Page and love it! It's a great place to go for a night cap. The lighting is sexy and the bartenders are very sweet!! The crowd is pretty chill.....
author: Cara- Jude S.

description: Nice people working there, fun and laid back crowd, Duvel, low ceilings, Photo Hunt. And after 2 Duvels, I'm glad it's near my house.
author: Melanie R.

description: I used to like this place a lot really but the staff has really been a pill the last couple of years.  The bartenders, really just the female ones, are quite stuckup and bitchy. They will come around and serve you when they feel like ending their conversation with the guy they are talking to at the end of the bar. There attitude is so bad they will make you feel like you are unwelcome and wasting their time. Maybe because I am a girl I don't know but they seem to have it out for me just about every time I go there, which is not often, maybe a couple of times a year. But funny how I have a similar experience every time... So unless you are with a big group of people and the bar is fairly busy (so that these girls actually have to work) I'd say skip it, there are much better and more pleasant places to hang out in this neighborhood.
author: Jen G.

description: I liked this bar a lot! Security helped me find a bus route home. Bartenders were sweet. Some of the customers were idiots, but welcome to lower Haight. I'll be back, for sure.
author: Dana F.

description:
cute place. it has a really comfortable vibe to it. the drinks were
super cheap. i'm used to paying $8-10 for drinks in chicago so $4.50
for a vodka seven is dirt cheap. it was like christmas! we came on a
saturday night so the place was packed. i'd come back.
author: Linda N.

description: My boyfriend is completely shy and will generally avoid going to bars with me at all costs, but I could see him loving The Page.  The bartenders and patrons are completely nice and laid back and the drinks are relatively cheap.  Plus they have foosball.
author: Katie S.

description:
when a bar gets it (and by "it", i mean MY drinking preference), then i am ecstatic. it's as if each time i arrive at a place and survey their bevvie optins and discover they have the ability to combine cider and lager and make magic, then it's christmas all over again. and not the depressing sort of christmas where you're stuck with the part of the family you didn't care to see, but the christmas where you're five and believe in santa again and there's snow outside. THAT sort of christmas..

the page is a favorite amongst friends. it was even fought over by one in their "divorce setllement" - it was actually a point of contention who could be seen at the page after the split. the bathrooms are small, but at least they're not as impersonal as, say, peeing in a trough at bar none. the pool tables (the page has two while most bars only have one) are a nice touch, even though i have yet to utilize them. and the supertouch in the front window is probably the best part. outside of the snakebites, that is..

do not have the following conversation at the bar, within earshot of the bartender, though:

person one: "what are we drinking next?"
person two: "alcohol? or beer? i was thinking beer."
person one: "ok. beer"

why shouldn't you have this conversation? because the page is one of very few places who carry ok beer, and you will be handed a bottle of the russian brew because the bartender thinks you just ordered it. i mean, go ahead and have that discussion, but when you're handed that bottle, don't say i didn't warn you.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: I give the Page five stars for one reason and one reason only....Erotic Photo Hunt, which is by far the raddest game ever!  Thank you Page.  You will always have a special place in my heart!
author: Christina S.

description: Solid dive bar with some great beers on tap. Lots of Irish folk hanging out, which is a good sign (unless there is some kind of hardcore football match going down, in which case it may still be a good sign, but you must have a high tolerance for being hit on by incredibly drunk Irishmen). There is a pool table in the back and there are tapestries on the wall featuring woodland creatures. Friendly vibe and lots of good eats nearby.
author: Angie R.

description: Seemed sketchy to me with lots of shady people venturing in and out of the bar. One perk though, which made the experience a little  better, was the internet juke box.  I'd say if you have a good group of friends to go with The Page wouldn't be too bad, but definitely not my first choice for a weekend night.
author: Amanda L.

description: Minus one star for lack of originality in the naming process. I only entered the bar formerly known as Chances once since the change over. It's lost the entire feel of what it used to be, but don't get me wrong, that is probably not a bad thing. Am curious as to how Page & Divis is considered Alamo Square....very perplexing.
author: Colleen B.

description: Considering I live practically as close as one can to The Page without actually living above it or inside or it I go here quite a lot.  Sometimes multiple times a week.  Great beer selection and good seating.
author: Katie M.

description: This bar is the closest to my house and I usually tell friends of mine to meet me there before a night of long-winded debauchery. But it's also a spot where I can watch a game on TV without being surrounded by too many hardcore sports fans. I watched the 2002 Super Bowl and several games of the last five World Series. The bathroom is awkward but not too bad when you're really drunk and I enjoy playing pool there because it's out of the way.
author: Klik W.

description: They have pear cider on tap! That's all I can say. Well, also, friendly bartender, great, old school bar area, and a modern juke box.
author: Macy R.

description: Ok I gave it an extra star because of the beer selection. I'll give it that because it is good and different. However, the jukebox is the absolute worst one in the history of bars. You need to pay extra to get what you want and I'm not sure it even stays in there so it's a huge money suckage machine. The cocktails are weakish, and sometimes they're strong so they're very inconsistent...the crowd is also inconsistent. So there's foozball and pool tables, one of the tables is located in the worst spot for it I believe and when it gets packed it really sucks. If I didn't live across the street....well, I do and I almost never go in here because I hear all the drunk douchebags outside all the time on the weekends. Oh and another thing, TVs do not make a bar. Ambiance is fairly cozy and the tables and chairs are pretty homey. And that's about it.
author: Gina R.

description: Pretty sure it changed it's name to The Page, but it's a great neighborhood bar...foosball table and all!  Perfect for the Haight St. bar crawl!
author: Sarah D.

description: This place is gathering some serious momentum.  It used to be sleepy.  Now, the list for getting a pool table is over 5 deep.  Bartenders are super friendly.  Juke box is solid -- you can download tunes to it that it didn't have.  Be sure to say Hi to Jessie -- the resident blonde Pool Shark.
author: Tim G.

description: A great escape if you're sick of Polk St sports bars.  Same kind of vibe, with a less post-frat guy crowd.  With a bar like this, I wish I lived in this neighborhood.
author: Wendy H.

description: No frills, no nonsense, neighborhood bar.  Nothing exciting, but it gets the job done.  Yes, friendly bartenders, foosball, and cool jukebox all a plus.
author: Christina D.

description:
great drinks...
great hipster crowd..
best jukebox...

played Doves over + over and no one minded
author: aynne v.

description: I liked it as Chances better, but have always had a pretty good time here.  Never been here at a busy time really.
author: Ed B.

description: I love this place, especially since it's one of the only bars (except for Madrone and Waziema) on Divis that serves hard alcohol. This bar has such a good feeling to it. I'm a big fan of bars that are throw-backs to another time. Another time where people are chill and unpretentious and wood paneling was acceptable. Pool tables are a definite plus.
author: Nicole C.

description: This place reminds me of a warm place on cold nights in Minnesota. They have the taps a flowing and the staff is friendly. I was in there when Barack won and the owner bought everyone a round. Definitely a good stop-in type place with a slightly older crowd and an air that's reminiscent of old school smoky bars from the seventies.
author: Devi G.

description: I had been trying to get to this bar when it was "Chances" but never made it. I have been twice in the last month or so; once on a Tuesday and again on a Friday. Tuesday night was very mellow but Friday was crowded. I liked the bartender and the few people that were there on a Tuesday were mellow. There is a pool table in the back with a good amount of seating for a large group. The Friday night that it was packed seemed to have a very lively crowd. I am glad this place is still a bar; the corner was empty for too long before they had Chances.
author: E P.

description:
This bar definitely has that neighborhood-y feel. If you're into that. But that could just be me since I only live a block and a half away. 

The good thing was that I went with six other people and we managed to sit together and all hear each other. The jukebox by the entrance looked pretty cool. I wanted to try it, but didn't get to 'cause I was wedged between our two tables. Overall, I think The Page is a good starting point but I was ready to move on by 1.5 of 3 drinks.
author: Jane C.

description: Fun neighborhood bar; nothing spectacular but nothing too shabby either.  Decent crowd, bonus points for Young's Double Chocolate Stout.
author: Alex K.

description: My local bar. Don't come here and order a martini and expect the world's best. In fact, don't order a martini at all. Don't order a mojito. Don't order a cosmo. Order a beer (the selection is usually great), a jack-and-coke, a scotch-and-soda, or a greyhound, and remind yourself where you are. Play some pool, sit on the stairs and talk about music, see your friends from college or from the neighborhood, take a nice walk home. Great Tuesday night bar.
author: kay v.

description: Good beer selection at reasonable prices.  Good whiskey selection.  Nice and dark.  Low, comfy chairs for relaxing with a beer and being able to talk to your friends.  2 pool tables and a foosball table (!!!).  Solid jukebox.  Overall, a great little dive bar.
author: matt c.

description:
your average neighborhood dive.  you can count on them. the drinks are always the same, the crowd is varied but local.  great for a first "meet" date.
jukebox, pool, and cozy chairs.  good old time bar.
author: regina k.

description: When you head it in feels like you have walked into some random bar in central CA (like Sonora) and they even have the prices to match (at least if you get there during happy hour).  Wide and frequently changing selection of great beers on tap and a full bar.  Only down-side is that it can get crowded and it is a pretty small space.
author: Chris G.

description: Nothing to call home about. Typically crowded on the weekends. Sometimes I'll play pool here.
author: George M.

description: The page is the type of place where its cool to hang out if its pretty empty, and even when its pretty packed because the people that go there are generally friendly and just neighborhood people in their 20s and 30s.  Great place to go after a show at the Independent.
author: Tony L.

description: After the track suit wearing chain smoking rein of Chances owners, the Page is an immense improvement.  The place used to have a coat of grime and crud but now feels clean and comfortable.  The owner is a super nice guy as is the bar staff.  It's great to have a local watering hole that serves more than beer with a good jukebox and pool table.
author: kathryn a.

description:
A little story before anything else:
The first time I got drunk off beer was with Zibby and we were drinking 40's of Mickeys.  After the first one I felt like I had reached my limit (boy have times changed!) but Zibby kept going strong.  About halfway through the second 40oz, he started with the trash-talking.  Calling me all sorts of names, pestering me not to be such a pussy and to just drink, etc.  A few minutes into his bantering and just before he was about to take another swig the scenario played out like this:
"You pus--"  BLARF.  *Zibby puking*
"Oh man, this suc--" BLARF *Zibby puking again*
"Dude, you're lucky you didn--" BLARF *Zibby yet again puking*
One of the few times that restraint on my part actually paid off.  Also one of the last times where a single 40oz could get me drunk.  
That being said, I've always known my cutoff point when it comes to booze.  Well, almost always.  But for whatever reason, The Page is *that* place for me where I test out my limits.  After a raucous night out when I should be heading home, I often go to the page for a last drink.  When I'm starving and the only thing I've had all day is booze, The Page is probably where you'll see me having a liquid meal.  Always full of relaxed and good people, always friendly bartenders, tons of beers on tap...a great place.  One of these days I should start out my night here instead of ending up here.
author: Zev K.

description: The barman knows what he is doing, there's pool and foosball downstairs, and taxidermy ornamenting the walls.  What more could you axe for?  Very good neighborhood corner bar.
author: Sam M.

description: Love this bar.  Friendly bar staff, great beer selection, foosball, pool, and awesome occasional liquor tastings (bourbon, scotch, gin, etc.).  The atmosphere here is exactly what I'm looking for when I need a cold beer.
author: John F.

description: A nice low key bar. Perfect for a date with someone who you would like to be able to hear during a conversation. Two pool tables, good beer, Great for weeknights too.
author: Dana H.

description: When this dive was chances it was a five star dive, now with new ownership and an even worse name, it looses a little streat cred.  Still the bartenders are all very sweet and the juke box rules
author: brian m.

description: This one is a keeper! The music in here is really good, but its misleading to say they have a good jukebox when its an interweb jukebox. I mean, regular jukeboxes only have so much space for music. This one has tons! So its not that the jukebox is good so much as it is the good taste of the patrons.
author: Andrew B.

description: Just recently moved into the neighborhood and I have to say the Page is by far our favorite bar in the area.  I think what I like most is that I can walk in there on a Tuesday or Friday and there is a good amount of people in the bar, not too crowded but not bare either.  Always a good time!
author: Kristin F.

description: The page is OK. It has a nice atmopshere about it and the drinks are fairly strong -- but at $8 for a double well mixed drink, I'd hope so. For the pool players, they have 2 tables that are well kept. Unfortunately this place gets really busy and it makes playing pool very hard. On top of that , the upstairs table has a wall in 2 places, making certain shots pretty much impossible. The crowd is usually very laid back and the have good tunes. Now that I think about it though, it is pretty sausage festy with all sorts of frat looking guys coming out in their abercrombie and old navy rags. This is a nice bar for happy hour during the week, but for the weekend you better be prepared to stand for a long period of time and get bumped into by a lot of people. 3 stars b/c of the drink prices and crowds.
author: Billy K.

description: The Page is a cool, little, neighborhood bar.  The night I was there it seemed to have mostly 20 and early 30 somethings from the surrounding blocks.  The have a couple of pool tables.  But the best feature is that they have a foosball table.  I was pretty happy drinking $2.50 Tacates.  The only negative was the very expensive digital juke box.
author: John S.

description: Best neighborhood by far. Good Jukebox, good crowd, mainly locals, good bartenders, pool tables. I like this place on a Tuesday night where I can sip on a Jameson and shoot some stick, or on a busy Friday night playing trivia in the corner taking Fernet shots and people watching. I like when places don;t try to be anything but what they are. So, whereas the Fly wants to be swanksville, the Madrone an artsy DJ hipster thing, The Page is just a bar, and they excel at being a bar, they put whiskey in my glasses, Heineken's in my hand, and memories from my nights, brilliant!!
author: Steve l.

description: This place is a descent local joint, but definitely nothing special.  If they had better drink prices then I'd give this place better marks, but providing a dive bar ambiance while charging premium prices kind of annoys me.
author: kiely c.

description: The best thing the Page has going for it is that it's the closest watering hole to my humble abode.  Decent beer selection, unpretentious crowd.  Good place to grab a beer and bitch about your week with a friend.  Probably not worth the trip if you're not in the neighborhood.
author: Arthur S.

description: meh. Every time I go to the Page, I think it will be lots of fun, and every time i walk back home, up the massive hill that is Divisadero, i wonder exactly why i thought it would be fun. It's possible i simply need to go there with different people than usual, but between the crowd and the volume, i am usually let down.
author: Manlio L.

description: I must admit I like this place when it is not pack full of people.  When it is packed it bottle necks into a very annoying bump and grind hallway.  Most of the female bartenders are cool.  One of them makes a dangerous Manhattan.  Got to say that it needs a little etiquette on the order of who is  next in the line but whatever.  Like I said best place to go to when it is not packed.
author: adams l.

description: The Page is awesome. They are remodeling this week (2/19) so they had a blowout on Sunday night were draft beers were a dollar. I got drunk and left some posters there because I came from a show at the Fillmore. I figured they were goners but i called the next day and they had put them aside for me. Cheers page, I will see you soon.
author: Sean K.

description: I've been coming here since it was Chances and I'm glad to say Bob, the new owner has not changed it too much. It's still a great place to go and watch or game or play some pool and have a beer or ten. All the bartenders are great and the vast majority of the crowd are laid back and just looking to relax and hang with friends.
author: Rick L.

description: I have enjoyed the Page before. But it seems that every time I am in there the bartenders ignore me for quite some time..no eye contact to acknowledge the patient patron waiting in the same spot someone else just ordered a drink at only to eventually ask for I.D and then walk away to rarely return in a timely fashion. (On this occasion to chop limes and not even glance up at all the other people waiting to order.) This last time, tonight, I just had to walk out. The service is consistently poor, and most often slow, or just plain non-existent.
author: Clyde M.

description:
It's kind of an upper-crust dive bar. Old school interior that's clean but not very roomy, with an odd assortment of decorations (animal heads, bad paintings).

Good selection of beers on tap - local & US micros, a few Belgians, and Shiner Bock.  When tired of beer, there's also a fairly wide range of whiskey and even some locally produced spirits.

If you get there before about 8:00 on any day of the week, there is no problem finding a seat and the average age is close to 40.  Later it turns young and crowded.
author: David S.

description: i love it here. it's actually just a normal bar, which is what i love most about it. the clientele is local in a way that feels more portland, maine than san francisco. this is a great place to have between one and nine drinks with a friend or a posse. so versatile like that.
author: julia r.

description: totally solid. pretty good sound track, medium-priced, medium service, standard '8' crowd.
author: Amber K.

description: Your classic neighborhood watering hole! It's dark, dingy and the walls are covered with dead stuffed animal heads. It's pretty awesome! Garrett is the best bouncer in the hood and will always welcome you with a smile.
author: Erica S.

description: i've been here a couple of times... it is pretty awesome early in the week. with a really mixed crowd of interesting people to watch and overhear.  and this is also the time when people seem to people really great stuff on the jukebox. but then comes the weekend... when this bar, just like any other, is some how overrun with fratty preppy college types. all of the sudden the music changes for the psychedelic furs to the latest horrible pop/hip hop tune. (read: umbrella ella ella ella ella barf). oh well... happy hour is good.  but not a lot of seating... so get there for happy hour... grab a stool.. and do.not.move.
author: Ashley A.

description: Worst vodka tonics I've ever had, and the place smells like a mix between corn and feet.  Didn't try the beer.
author: Rachael S.

description: Inside, The Page is a full fledged salute to rumpus rooms of the late 60's and early 70's. Tons of vintage lamps with red bulbs, various animals heads staring you down, two pool tables, etc. Drinks are reasonably priced and they have a nice selection of beer (I really enjoyed the Anchor Steam Christmas Ale). The bartenders might, however, benefit from the understanding that people come in to actually spend money there and deserve only a minimal amount of courtesy. That is, of course, unless I accidentally got this place confused with the San Francisco location of the Dick's Last Resort restaurant chain. 4+ star place, 2- star service.
author: Greg H.

description: good friendly neighborhood bar.  don't come here to find a scene.  it's just local peeps hanging out.  ok maybe one or 2 hipsters.
author: Julia H.

description: I used to love this bar, but now I can barely ever find a table here.  Plus, don't expect to hear your music played on the juke box.
author: Sarah K.

description: Not worth even one star!  The cliental there is trashy and run their mouths.  Guess that's what happens when you have a thug bouncer.  Angry people at this place...watch your back here!
author: Nichole K.

description: the page aka my living room.  home sweet home.
author: Jeni D.

description: i too am in love with this bar.  probably because a majority of their clientele are just like me- want to play a nice game of pool, while listening to some good tunes and drinking some pbr.  caution: the tables are packed at this place and the bar is way too crowded thursday-saturday night.  all other nights, the page is a great place to relax after a hard days work.
author: rachface -.

description: nice neighborhood bar. great place to chill if you're in no mood to venture from the lower haight and don't want to deal with haight street.
author: Dean E.

description: good local bar without much attitude.  should open earlier tho.  hard to get a cocktail before 5 in the area  - gotta go to molotov.
author: eeeee d.

description: i love this bar. its laid back. strong drinks and weird and cute people. beardy dudes to flirt with. if i leave the mission or the phone booth closes ever, this would be my regular dive spot. but i do hate the girls that always put stupid shit on the jukebox. the same 2 girls like everytime i go in there. i may have to give them a beat down if they keep it up.
author: kelly M.

description: Although I was once criticized by the bartender for ordering one of their "girly" cosmos (note: it was actually for a lady), I've designated the Page my Official Preferred Watering Hole (which is quite a hefty title to wield). The decor reminds me of my parents basement (pre-1980s remodelling effort), the music (internet jukebox) consists of a great mix, but is not overpoweringly loud, and there's a foosball table that is generally not in use (until I arrive).
author: nick m.

description: It seems like it could be a decent place, but every time I've been in, it's completely crowded with people who don't seem anything like the people I see everywhere else in my neighborhood, and I mean that in a bad way. The lower Haight is a relatively mellow area, and particularly this spot on Divisadero is almost exactly between the upper and lower Haight, so it's not too inundated by revelers destined for either, but for some reason whenever I go to the Page, I get flashbacks to the undergrad asshats who made me loathe going out in Santa Cruz. Where the hell are these people coming from?
author: Cooper B.

description: This is great bar to sit down at and drink with friends.  Very casual and comfortable.  Nothing pretentious about it at all.  Good selection, good prices, excellent bartenders.  Cash only is a drag.
author: Mason K.

description: this feels like a real neighborhood bar. plenty of spots within walking distance which makes for a nice pub crawl.
author: Jeff B.

description: seems a bit out of place fo the city.  nothing pretentious about this place.  decent beer and enough space to sit down.
author: pauline e.
